'Doctor Dog'

Autor: Trusty, Sheri. 

Información de publicación: The News - Messenger ; Fremont, Ohio [Fremont, Ohio]. 17 Dec 2019: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/doctor-dog/docview/2327226881/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=%27Doctor+Dog%27%3A+Catawba+beagle+named+Oscar+featured+in+book+highlighting+medical+alert+dogs+around+the+world&amp;author=Trusty%2C+Sheri&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2019-12-17&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+News+-+Messenger&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: PORT CLINTON – A Catawba Island beagle named Oscar is one of the dogs featured in the book "Doctor Dogs" by New York Times bestselling author Maria Goodavage
The book highlights medical alert dogs from around the world. Oscar was abandoned by his previous owner before Deanne "DeeDee" Kramer and her late husband, Bill, adopted him as a walking companion. But Oscar did more than become a walking buddy. He saved their lives.
Bill was struggling with complications from diabetes, which kept sending him to the emergency room several times a month. Finally, his doctor told him he needed to get a dog to help him become more active.
"We couldn't handle a lab," DeeDee said. "And then we heard about Oscar."
Oscar's first rescue came before he had any training. When Bill collapsed from a heart attack, Oscar, barking, ran to DeeDee to let her know. The incident exposed Oscar's intelligence and potential, and the Kramers decided to see if he could be trained as a diabetic alert dog to alert Bill when his blood sugar levels changed. Their search for a trainer eventually brought them to Nick and Tammy Blackford of North Coast K-9, who have offices in Sandusky and Monroeville. Nick, who has been training dogs since 1974, has trained many of the area's police dogs.
Oscar excelled through 500 hours of training, which included Canine Good Citizen, therapy dog, and public access training. His training to detect blood sugar level changes was intensive.
"He had to pass three tests before he could even start scent training," DeeDee said. "It's no different than training a drug dog, because it's all about smell."
To prepare for the training, Bill spit on cotton balls when his sugar was high and when his sugar was low. Nick placed those cotton balls, along with other cotton balls, in containers around the training facility. When Oscar found the right cotton ball, he was rewarded.
As a result, Oscar was able to detect when Bill's sugar changed. If it was high, he pawed on Bill's knees. If it was low, he pushed his nose into Bill's face.
"He was 10 minutes faster than the meter," DeeDee said. "After Oscar got trained, Bill had zero emergency room visits."
After Bill died, DeeDee's mourning kept her from caring for herself the way she normally did, and her hypoglycemia began to worsen. Now, Oscar alerts her when her blood sugar reaches dangerous levels.
"If I'm driving, he'll come from the back of the car and make me pull over," DeeDee said.
Dogs can be trained to respond to medical emergencies in a variety of ways that suit their owners' needs.
"Some are trained to bark so if the person is in another room with the door shut, the dog can still alert them," Nick said.
In addition to helping the Kramers, Oscar detected cancer in DeeDee's friend. The story of that miraculous rescue is recorded in "Doctor Dogs."
"He wasn't even trained for that," DeeDee said.
Oscar also accompanies DeeDee when she volunteers at the Ohio Veterans Home in Sandusky each week. He not only spreads love while he's there, but he also detects blood sugar levels in the veterans he visits.
DeeDee said it's not unusual for beagles to be trained as alert dogs because their ability to smell is so acute.
"Basset hounds are good, too," she said. "But if you want a diabetic alert dog, go to trainer, and they will find one suited to you. Don't just go out and get a puppy."
For more information on the book, "Doctor Dogs," visit mariagoodavage.com.
While Oscar's big eyes can melt hearts, his nose can save lives. Even though he was trained as a diabetic alert dog, he detected cancer in his owner's friend.
Sheri Trusty/Correspondent

Lakewood immigrants support NJ license bill

Autor: CONTRERAS, GUSTAVO MARTNEZ. 

Información de publicación: Asbury Park Press ; Asbury Park, N.J. [Asbury Park, N.J]. 17 Dec 2019: A.4.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/lakewood-immigrants-support-nj-license-bill/docview/2327224484/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Lakewood+immigrants+support+NJ+license+bill&amp;author=CONTRERAS%2C+GUSTAVO+MARTNEZ&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;date=2019-12-17&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Asbury+Park+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: LAKEWOOD – If state lawmakers needed a nudge on the issue of extending New Jersey driver's licenses to immigrants without legal status, a contingent from this town was on hand to provide it.
Ahead of Monday's legislative action in Trenton, some 100 area residents — mostly from Lakewood, here without authorization and pining to drive legally — boarded a bus and filled vans and SUVs, aiming to demonstrate their support for the measure.
Many told the Press they saw the license bill as key to expanding opportunity for jobs and better housing. They said they wanted to be on hand for what they hoped would be a historic day — as important as any in ensuring a better future.
"Can't say I'm dancing with joy because it's too cold," local activist Norma Morales, 45, said in Spanish. "I was expecting 100 people tops, but many more showed up and members of our community are coming through with their own vehicles to take people there."
While Morales was busy making calls to coordinate rides to Trenton, others waited on the bus, for what they hoped would be a final push in a long overdue fight.
"We're going there to represent the thousands of people who cannot make it there today, those who need a license because they can't take their children to school or to the doctor, those of us who need a license," Víctor Cortez, 36, said in Spanish. "We're here for the people and with the people."
A construction worker, Cortez asked for the day off from work, despite the loss of pay. He said it was more important to join the group heading to Trenton and provide an example for his three U.S.-born children.
"This will give them an example when in the future they need something, they go out and fight for what their community needs, to go look for it and not be hoping somebody will make the decision for themselves," he said. "What we do is an example that we will pass onto our children."
Proponents of the measure said passage would be life-changing. Hours later, both the Assembly and the Senate endorsed the legislation, sending the landmark change to Gov. Phil Murphy.
While unauthorized immigrants have been barred from obtaining a driver's license in the Garden State, the reality is many are on the road anyway — with and without insurance and often with out-of-state documents — to get to work, the grocery store or doctor's appointments, immigrants and their advocates say.
The Garden State is home to more than 466,000 unauthorized immigrants of driving age, according to a 2018 report by the think tank NJ Policy Perspective.
About 233,000 unauthorized immigrants would become licensed drivers within three years of approval, the report concludes.
It's unclear how many are driving now, but the policy group and other bill proponents argue the roads would be safer with more motorists properly trained, tested and insured.
In New York, Monday also marked the start of that state's allowing those previously ineligible to get driver's licenses to apply. The New York Times reported that lines at state Department of Motor Vehicles offices "snaked around buildings" in New York City.
The Times reported that at a Bronx location, workers went outside around 12:30 p.m. to tell those waiting in line that the office's testing room was full.
Murphy, long a proponent of the license bill for New Jersey, has said he would sign it into law.
Gustavo Martínez Contreras covers Lakewood. He is a graduate of the University of Texas at El Paso and the Newmark Graduate School of Journalism at the City University of New York. Contact him at gmartinez@gannettnj.com or at 732-643-4061.

Impeachment Week: American Voices

Información de publicación: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]. 17 Dec 2019: A.26.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/impeachment-week-american-voices/docview/2327194756/se-2?accountid=14708

Texto completo: Readers react to The Times's editorial calling for the impeachment of President Trump, and to a news article about the likely trial in the Senate.
To the Editor:
Re "Impeach." (editorial, Dec. 15):
Thank you for a crystal-clear argument for impeachment. This should be part of the House presentation to the Senate.
Maybe truth can still win.
Herb Passberger
Glen Cove, N.Y.
To the Editor:
Americans are not grasping the importance of the impeachment proceedings and not taking them seriously because they do not see Donald Trump as a serious man in a profoundly serious position. He is perceived as if he were the star of a media show, "The White House."
Mr. Trump has diminished the office with barrages of tweets, public insults, veiled threats and grandstanding. His presidency now seems to be on a par with football games, sitcoms and quiz shows.
This is a dangerous situation; let's hope that the American public starts paying attention.
Shirley Stuart
Berkeley, Calif.
To the Editor:
As bad as President Trump's shakedown of a struggling Ukraine is, the House and Senate Republicans are worse. All of them are deliberately damaging this country even further by consciously working to deepen the divisions among Americans.
They support Mr. Trump's lies; they viciously attack their colleagues on the other side of the aisle; they repeat over and over again their own lies; they say everything they can dream up to defend the indefensible and to weaken this incredible Constitution of ours.
If the Republicans were true to their oath to protect and defend the Constitution, they would actually listen to the witnesses' sworn testimony. They are not even trying to discover the truth; they are simply making a sham out of this very serious process.
If they acted honestly, they would do much to educate the American public and help heal the divisions in this country.
Mary C. Helf
Flourtown, Pa.
To the Editor:
If the defense of the Constitution and the Republic are in the hands of the Democratic-controlled House of Representatives to impeach President Trump for the reasons argued in your editorial, the country is in big trouble.
Fortunately, the Republican-controlled Senate will restore sanity by acquitting the president, and American voters will have the last word on Election Day 2020 when they re-elect Mr. Trump, restore Republicans to the House majority and retain Republican control of the Senate.
Then, the Republic will not only endure, but it will also prevail and prosper.
Dennis L. Breo
New Smyrna Beach, Fla.
To the Editor:
Of course he will -- must -- be impeached. But as far as I know, President Trump is not entitled to a speedy trial in the Senate, where he can count on "jurors" who ordinarily would be excused for cause. A case in point is Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, who has said he will be coordinating with the White House counsel in the process.
Also, Senator Lindsey Graham has pre-empted and rendered false the oath he will take to be fair by having decided the matter before considering the evidence. He should of course be excused.
Consequently, there is good reason for the House -- representatives of the people, not the president -- to delay sending the articles of impeachment to the Senate. At a minimum, it could give those who seek a fair trial the leverage to gain one by delaying until they are assured the right to call witnesses.
But even more critical, a delay might prevent Mr. Trump from rigging another game while allowing the House to pursue his numerous other offenses against the country.
Nancy Luque
New York
The writer is a lawyer.
To the Editor:
Re "Schumer Frames Full Senate Trial on Impeachment" (front page, Dec. 16):
Be careful what you wish for.
Seeking relevant documents is one thing. But the notion that Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff; Secretary of State Mike Pompeo; the former national security adviser John Bolton and others will come before the Senate and glibly pour out the true facts about Ukraine and the transparently false explanations by President Trump is a bit of a pipe dream.
Look back to what we've got from Attorney General William Barr; the former acting attorney general Matthew Whitaker; the former Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski; and the former special counsel Robert Mueller, for that matter, who when given the opportunity to enlighten Congress and the public on matters of importance, chose obfuscation or near silence.
James P. Pehl
Marlborough, Mass.

Top Helmet Maker Losing Money Fast

Autor: Belson, Ken; Draper, Kevin. 

Información de publicación: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]. 17 Dec 2019: B.9.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/top-helmet-maker-losing-money-fast/docview/2327194266/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Top+Helmet+Maker+Losing+Money+Fast%3A+%5BSports+Desk%5D&amp;author=Belson%2C+Ken%3BDraper%2C+Kevin&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.9&amp;date=2019-12-17&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;issn=0362-4331&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anytimes_

Texto completo: Vicis, which has won more than $ 1 million in grants from the N.F.L. and makes helmets used by star quarterbacks like Russell Wilson and Patrick Mahomes, is running out of money.
Around Thanksgiving, Aaron Rodgers and Russell Wilson received some news as unnerving as the sight of an all-out quarterback blitz.
The N.F.L. stars and other investors in Vicis, the heralded Seattle-based helmet maker, were officially informed that the company was running out of cash.
"Our employees are currently furloughed and we need to raise capital in order to continue operating, or we may have no other option but to wind down all operations," wrote Ralph Greene Jr., who took over as the new chief executive just days before, in a letter reviewed by The New York Times.
The plea for millions of dollars to cover basic expenses represents a startling fall for a company that has won plaudits for its high-tech helmets and raised more than $ 90 million from venture capital and some of the N.F.L.'s highest-profile players. The company, with a board that includes highly respected doctors, business leaders and military advisers, also secured $ 1.1 million in grants from the N.F.L., though the league does not have an ownership stake.
The financial crisis at Vicis highlights one of the biggest challenges in football's fight to make the game safer. Most brain scientists dismiss the idea that a new helmet can significantly reduce the risk of traumatic brain injuries and long-term brain damage.
Wilson, Kansas City Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes and dozens of other players wear a Vicis helmet each Sunday. Shock absorbers inside the helmet have been shown to reduce the impact of direct hits and limit the rotational energy the head absorbs. So far, that has not been enough for Vicis to succeed.
Youth and high school football participation is falling, and the helmet business is dominated by Riddell and a handful of companies that are weighed down by insurance costs. Still, Vicis and other companies continue to try to develop better helmets for athletes and other commercial and military uses.
In its letter to investors, the company said it would try to raise additional money by selling shares that valued the company at just $ 5 million, compared with a $ 90 million valuation as recently as last year.
To stay afloat, Vicis plans to cut operating costs by half, curtail expansion plans and focus on just two football helmets -- its adult model and a version for children. Last month, the company's board pushed out its co-founder and chief executive, Dave Marver, who said in an email that the odds were stacked against newcomers to the helmet business, even those like Vicis that have seen growth.
"We were more successful than most at raising capital, but it took a tremendous amount of time and effort, effort that could have been applied to growing and running the business," Marver said.
The company expects to lose $ 26 million this year, according to internal Vicis documents. With its cash dwindling, it has struggled to fulfill some orders. The delivery of a few hundred helmets ordered by the upstart X.F.L. has been delayed. The new league is hoping the helmets will arrive by the start of training camps early next year, according to an X.F.L. official with direct knowledge of the transaction, who spoke on condition of anonymity to preserve the league's relationship with one of the few helmet manufacturers.
In a statement, Matt McKenna, a spokesman for Vicis, said the company is seeking another round of funding. He declined to comment further.
Vicis approached the helmet market in the fashion of Tesla, the automobile maker that sought to capture the high-end of the market first. Vicis targeted N.F.L. and college teams that can afford its premium prices. The helmets can cost as much as $ 1,500, at least double what most high-end helmets cost. Executives hoped the visibility among top athletes would help them sell to youth and high school teams.
But the challenges for a newcomer, even one with the support and star power of Vicis, are fierce, said Vin Ferrara, who founded and ran the helmet maker Xenith for almost a decade. There are liability and product maintenance costs, helmets that need to be customized for players and teams, and a limited market that tightens competition.
"It is entirely conceivable that even if a helmet were designed and tested such that it could undeniably claim it was better, it could fail as a commercial product," Ferrara said.
Still, Vicis appeared to have advantages. Two professors from the University of Washington and Marver, a veteran of the medical device business, launched the company in 2013. Its association with the N.F.L. and support from Commissioner Roger Goodell helped immensely.
"How do we use new materials, how do we use new technology to create a better helmet?" Goodell said at a fan forum in 2017 where he touted Vicis. "We have one that's hitting the market this year. It was developed by somebody in Seattle." In an interview last year, Marver said the backing of the N.F.L. had given Vicis credibility with the medical and equipment staffs of N.F.L. teams.
"They should be proud of the work they have done," Jeff Miller, the league's executive vice president for health and safety innovation, said of Vicis engineers in a statement issued on Monday. "It has contributed to a significant shift in the helmet manufacturing industry that benefits players at the professional level and beyond."
Another source of capital has been Rx3 Ventures, a consumer-focused investment fund based in California. Aaron Rodgers, the Green Bay Packers quarterback, is a partner. The private equity fund was an early investor in Vicis, even though Rodgers doesn't wear its helmets. (He wears a helmet from competitor Schutt.)
The Vicis board includes Richard Ellenbogen, a neurosurgeon in Seattle who was chairman of the league's Head, Neck and Spine Committee. Other players who have invested include the New York Giants receiver Golden Tate (who also wears the helmet), the former receiver Doug Baldwin, and Hall of Famers Jerry Rice and Roger Staubach.
The N.F.L. and the players union ranked the company's ZERO1 model at the top of its 2019 helmet rankings based on its ability to "reduce head impact severity." The outside of the ZERO1 is softer than other helmets and has columns that deform upon impact, helping distribute force more evenly than other helmets do.
However, according to the N.F.L., helmets from Vicis competitors Riddell, Schutt and Xenith are about as good. The league noted in its testing that some two dozen approved helmets also performed well in testing, with "no statistical difference in performance from the three top-ranked helmets."
The company has said that about 7 percent of N.F.L. players wear the ZERO1, and the company has begun equipping college players. The first Vicis expansion into colleges, with the University of Oregon and University of Washington, led to complaints from players about the fit.
The cost of developing Vicis's technology has far outpaced the sale of new helmets. The company expects to take in $ 14.2 million in revenue in 2019, according to financial reports reviewed by The Times, about $ 3 million less than the cost of producing its helmets. Costs associated with sales, marketing and research and development are expected to push the losses to $ 25.9 million this year.
The company anticipates even less revenue next year, but because of a dramatic cost-cutting, it forecasts a loss of $ 9 million.
Before he was pushed out, Marver had to scramble for more money.
"It's always difficult for a company making football helmets to raise capital given the industry's risks and competitive dynamics," Marver said. "Most institutional investors won't engage at all."
According to notices filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company in July tried to raise $ 10 million, but was only able to come up with $ 2.1 million. The company had to pay a broker $ 112,000 to find these additional investors.
Photograph Russell Wilson, above, and Patrick Mahomes, left, wear helmets made by Vicis, which has secured $ 1.1 million in grants from the N.F.L. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY MATT ROURKE/ASSOCIATED PRESS; CHARLES KRUPA/ASSOCIATED PRESS) (B9): Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers, center at left, is an investor in Vicis, although he wears a helmet from a competing company, Schutt. (PHOTOGRAPH BY EZRA SHAW/GETTY IMAGES) (B11)

Materia: Institutional investments; College football; Helmets; Costs; High school football

Lugar: New York Kansas City Missouri California

Alexander: What if the Raiders had gotten first shot at L.A.?

Autor: Alexander, Jim. 

Información de publicación: The Sun ; San Bernardino, Calif. [San Bernardino, Calif]. 16 Dec 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/alexander-what-if-raiders-had-gotten-first-shot/docview/2327546005/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Alexander%3A+What+if+the+Raiders+had+gotten+first+shot+at+L.A.%3F&amp;author=Alexander%2C+Jim&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-12-16&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Sun&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Awestnews_

Texto completo: The thought first occurred to me five weeks ago, while watching the Oakland Raiders’ pass rush treat Philip Rivers like one of those inflatable pop-up dolls – you know, you keep knocking it down, and it keeps bouncing right back up – on the field at whatever they’re calling the Oakland-Alameda Coliseum these days.
It continued to nag at me during all of these weeks the Chargers have been on the road. It kept coming to mind Sunday, when they returned home to play before what would be conservatively estimated as 70 percent Minnesota Vikings fans, at the same time the Raiders were making their own melancholy farewell appearance in Oakland.
Today then, a few days before the Raiders and a chunk of their immense SoCal fan base play the Chargers in Carson, it’s time for some alternate history.
What would have happened, at that fateful NFL league meeting in January 2016 when Stan Kroenke’s fellow owners approved the Rams’ move to L.A. and his Inglewood stadium project, if those owners had given the Raiders the first option to become Kroenke’s tenant, rather than the Chargers?
We start this musing with an opinion that I’d maintained throughout the two decades of the league’s absence from L.A., when the city was no more than a stalking horse for other owners seeking stadium deals in their own cities: If and when a team finally set up shop here, it would have to deal with that huge segment of fans who refused to abandon the Silver and Black even after Al Davis moved the Raiders back to their ancestral home in 1995.
Those are the people you’ve seen in the Southwest Airlines terminals of area airports on Saturdays (or Sunday mornings) of Raiders home game weekends the last 25 seasons, flying up to the games and flying back afterward. Some are clad in their Black Hole costumes, and I’m guessing TSA employees have to remind themselves: These aren’t security risks, these are Raider fans.
(Feel free to insert your own one-liner here.)
Their commutes will be shorter beginning next season when the Raiders move into the $2 billion Allegiant Stadium near the Las Vegas strip.
But stay with me here: What if the Raiders had wound up in L.A. … and the Chargers had wound up in Vegas, a virgin territory with no previous NFL allegiances beyond monetary ones? It’s not that far-fetched.
From the Raiders’ standpoint, I’m guessing they would have found an immediate home somewhere in SoCal. Probably not the Coliseum, likely not the Rose Bowl, but possibly Dodger or Angel Stadium as a short-term abode. They would have had no trouble filling it with their own loyal (and eccentrically costumed) fans, while the Rams would still have been able to rebuild their SoCal fan base in much the same manner they have. There would be less snark about L.A. as an NFL town, and when the Inglewood stadium was ready the new occupants would be on relatively equal footing.
(You think the Raiders aren’t still strong here? There are still Raider Image stores at Universal Citywalk and in Moreno Valley, and the team’s fan club directory lists nine different booster clubs in SoCal, from Fillmore to Hesperia and including two in San Diego.)
But what of the Chargers?
Before I continue, I am fully aware that this column will likely draw a call or a text from the Chargers’ sharp vice president of public relations, Josh Rupprecht, asking what his franchise did to deserve this, and is it really a bad thing that the Chargers are here? We realize this is considered a long-term project to build a fan base. But three years in, you have to wonder if this market – the most diverse, and fickle, in North America – just might be too tough to crack.
Certainly, people in the NFL offices in New York are noticing. And the reports of friction between the Chargers and Rams involving the new stadium, now a $5 billion (and rising) project, don’t help the optics.
The Las Vegas component will not thrill our friends in San Diego, but consider the history of these moves.
When Mark Davis and the Raiders romanced Las Vegas early in 2016, no more than a couple of weeks after (a) their joint project with the Chargers on a new Carson stadium was shot down and (b) the Chargers got the first option to join Kroenke’s project with a year to exercise it, the man who arranged the Raiders-Vegas talks was Mark Fabiani. That is the same Fabiani who is still listed in the Chargers’ organizational chart as a special counsel to controlling owner Dean Spanos, and the same Fabiani who was in charge of the team’s stadium quest in San Diego.
Also, in many eyes – including these two – it’s the same Fabiani who torpedoed any chance of cooperation between Spanos’ organization and the politicians of San Diego with an uncompromising, hardball negotiating style that ultimately led to a total breakdown of relationships with city officials and the fans themselves. The moment the Chargers began openly seeking other alternatives was the moment the San Diego public began to turn away from Spanos and his team.
Fabiani later signed on as an advisor to Las Vegas casino mogul Sheldon Adelson, and it was through that relationship that Mark Davis was introduced to Adelson and the wheels began to turn toward the Raiders’ move to Nevada.
So, in our alternate history, it is entirely reasonable that having been shut out of L.A., Spanos turns his attention north on I-15, with Fabiani smoothing the way for the Chargers in the same way he made things happen for the Raiders.
Those bridge years might still have been spent in San Diego, and it’s possible the composition of crowds in that city would resemble what they are now in Carson. But Las Vegas would ultimately have been a far more hospitable destination for the Chargers, as a one-team town hungry for football. Spanos would have been a hero, rather than an interloper (as he’s considered by many in L.A.) or villain (in San Diego).
Plus it’s a lot closer than London, where reports earlier this season had the Chargers ultimately landing followed by Spanos’ vehement denial.
Instead, back in the real world, this is what we have: Minnesota Vikings fans dominating Dignity Health Sports Park this past Sunday, just like Green Bay Packers fans before them, and Pittsburgh Steelers fans, Denver Broncos fans, Houston Texans fans and Indianapolis Colts fans before that in 2019. It has to be discouraging for players and coaches who never get to play before a true home crowd.
The move to the bigger SoFi Stadium will not be a panacea – it’s more seats available for opposition fans, if anything – and while there will be an attempt to put the teams on equal footing in the shared stadium, it will be hard to forget that Kroenke is the owner and Spanos is the renter.
Meanwhile, SoCal Raiders fans will continue to flock to LAX, Burbank, Ontario, Long Beach and John Wayne airports to catch flights for their favorite team’s home games, or else will make the drive up I-15. As colleague Mark Whicker once observed, it’ll be like eight more championship fights a year in ‘Vegas.
An example: The New York Times quoted Ruben Maya, a law enforcement officer from Riverside who paid $12,000 for two personal seat licenses and $3,000 for 2020 season tickets for Raiders games in Vegas: “I live a six-hour drive from Oakland, but it’s only a 3-1/2 hour drive to Las Vegas. I’m going to come to every home game the first season.”
And, as has been the case for years, the Raiders’ ninth home game will come on the Chargers’ home field. There will be a preview Sunday afternoon.
jalexander@scng.com
@Jim_Alexander on Twitter

Liberal Media Scream: New York Times' columnist demands impeachment ‘to preserve America'

Autor: Bedard, Paul. 

Información de publicación: Washington Examiner ; Washington, D.C. [Washington, D.C]. 16 Dec 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/liberal-media-scream-new-york-times-columnist/docview/2327290574/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Liberal+Media+Scream%3A+New+York+Times%27+columnist+demands+impeachment+%26lsquo%3Bto+preserve+America%27&amp;author=Bedard%2C+Paul&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-12-16&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Washington+Examiner&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: This week’s Liberal Media Scream features celebrated New York Times columnist Thomas Friedman declaring that only impeaching President Trump will preserve the nation.
In a “Point-CounterPoint” segment on CBS’s Sunday Morning, Friedman declared: “President Trump not only should be impeached, he must be impeached, if we’re to preserve America as we’ve known it.”
iFrame Object
Responding to Eliana Johnson of the Washington Free Beacon, who argued against impeaching Trump, Friedman began his counterpoint:
“President Trump not only should be impeached, he must be impeached, if we’re to preserve America as we’ve known it. Of course, ideally, presidents should be removed by the will of voters through elections. But, Eliana, when I hear Trump defenders say impeachment would subvert that process, I say: ‘Really? What the hell do you think Trump was doing?’ He was subverting the will of the people by using our tax dollars to force Ukraine to investigate his most feared opponent, Joe Biden, in the next election, rather than trusting voters to do that.
“If we say, as Republicans are, that what Trump did is not impeachable, we are telling ourselves and every future president, ‘Hey, it’s okay to enlist a foreign power to tilt the election your way.’ Can you imagine how much cash future candidates could raise from Saudi Arabia or how many cyber warriors they could enlist from Russia to tilt future elections? The sanctity of our elections would be shot, and we’d never again have a president, who, whether or not you liked him or her, was at least seen as legitimately elected.”
Brent Baker, Media Research Center vice president of research, explains our weekly pick: “Friedman is certainly in high dudgeon with his claim that ‘to preserve America as we’ve known it,’ President Trump must be impeached, as if not impeaching Trump will ruin the country. He’d have more credibility to pass such moral judgment if he’d not shown over the top disdain for Trump since Trump was elected. ‘This is a moral 9/11. Only 9/11 was done to us from the outside, and we did this to ourselves,’ Friedman told Bill Maher three days after the 2016 vote.
Rating: Four out of five screams.

Bloomberg, Booker, and Castro may make February debates if rule changes go through

Autor: Larsen, Emily. 

Información de publicación: Washington Examiner ; Washington, D.C. [Washington, D.C]. 16 Dec 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/bloomberg-booker-castro-may-make-february-debates/docview/2327289518/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Bloomberg%2C+Booker%2C+and+Castro+may+make+February+debates+if+rule+changes+go+through&amp;author=Larsen%2C+Emily&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-12-16&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Washington+Examiner&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: Democratic presidential candidates unlikely to make the January debate stage may get a reprieve from pending rules changes that could clear the way for Cory Booker, Michael Bloomberg, and Julian Castro to participate.
Tom Perez, Democratic National Committee chair, told the New York Times that both a polling and donor threshold for debate qualification will remain in place for the Jan. 14 debate in Iowa, a blow to the eight candidates who failed to meet the mark for the December round and have a lower chance of meeting it for the January round.
Booker, a New Jersey senator, and eight other presidential candidates — seven who qualified for the December debate plus Castro, a former housing secretary — signed a letter sent to the DNC on Saturday urging the committee to change the bar for qualification to either a donor threshold or a polling threshold rather than both.
“The escalating thresholds over the past few months have unnecessarily and artificially narrowed what started as the strongest and most diverse Democratic field in history before voters have had a chance to be heard,” the letter read.
Participation for the December debate required candidates to secure 200,000 donors plus meet a polling threshold of either 4% support in four DNC-approved primary polls or 6% support in two early state polls. Debate requirements have steadily increased for the six debates in 2016, but Perez did not say whether the DNC would again raise the bar for January.
Booker, Castro, and Hawaii Rep. Tulsi Gabbard met the December donor threshold but did not secure the required polls. Five other candidates did not meet either metric: Colorado Sen. Michael Bennet, Bloomberg, former Maryland Rep. John Delaney, former Massachusetts Gov. Deval Patrick, and spiritual author Marianne Williamson.
There could be hope for the candidates to make the three debates scheduled in February, though. Perez said he might eliminate the thresholds or use results from early state nominating contests as a new qualifying threshold.
Eliminating a donor threshold is the only way that Bloomberg, a billionaire and former New York mayor, could participate in the debates because he is self-funding his campaign and not accepting outside donations.
Perez said that he hears complaints about debate rules from both sides.
“I’ve had days where I’ve gotten calls, literally, one after another, from person A, who I have great respect for, who said, ‘You’ve got to help. We need a narrower field,’” Perez said. “Then person B calls saying, ‘The field is too narrow.’”
Photo Caption:Chair of the Democratic National Committee, Tom Perez, speaks before a Democratic presidential primary debate, Wednesday, Nov. 20, 2019, in Atlanta. (AP Photo/John Bazemore)

Covington 2: Newsrooms falsely accuse West Point cadets of flashing ‘white supremacy’ symbol

Autor: Adams, T. 

Información de publicación: Washington Examiner ; Washington, D.C. [Washington, D.C]. 16 Dec 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/covington-2-newsrooms-falsely-accuse-west-point/docview/2327289274/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Covington+2%3A+Newsrooms+falsely+accuse+West+Point+cadets+of+flashing+%26lsquo%3Bwhite+supremacy%26rsquo%3B+symbol&amp;author=Adams%2C+T&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-12-16&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Washington+Examiner&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: Here we go again. Call it the sequel to the Covington Catholic scandal.
West Point cadets were seen this weekend on national television playing the “circle game,” an old schoolyard pastime where a person makes a circle with his thumb and index finger and then punches whomever he tricks into looking at it. But certain journalists and pundits did not see cadets merely playing a silly game before the Army-Navy football game. Rather, members of our very serious and reasonable news media saw cadets flashing the “OK” hand gesture supposedly owned by white supremacists.
Clearly, we have learned nothing from the Covington Catholic fiasco, an especially shameful episode in media malpractice for which several publications now face multimillion-dollar defamation lawsuits.
The jarringly stupid Army-Navy episode begins with an obscure Twitter user, @BruthaManTho, who tweeted photos of ESPN’s broadcast with the accompanying commentary, “Just wanted to enjoy the #ArmyNavy. Didn’t expect or want to see the White Power symbol thrown up by cadets on national television.”
The person added, “They are well aware of what they are doing and think it’s funny. Disgusting. … nothing like seeing a bunch of cadets throwing up the white power symbol on national television.”Tweet
The tweets soon went viral, creating an entire news cycle based around the laugh-out-loud assertion that cadets playing the "circle game" had displayed “white power” symbols on national television.

The New York Times, for example, published an article on the incident on Sunday explaining how the "OK" hand gesture has "became a fraught one.”

This is so stupid. I genuinely resent everyone for making me explain this.

First, the “OK” symbol that members of the press and activist groups attribute to white supremacists started as a joke. Trolls on the internet thought it would be funny to trick the broader media into believing that a universally accepted hand gesture was part of a secret code used by white supremacists (the New York Times article mentions all of this). The “OK” gesture then became an inside joke among actual white supremacists, which resulted in activist groups and the press declaring the innocuous symbol off-limits for everyone.
In other words, the "OK" sign is "fraught" because the targets of a joke campaign by online trolls say so.

Secondly, the “OK” hand gesture attributed to white supremacists is right-side up (fingers pointing upwards). The hand gestures seen on national television this weekend at the Army-Navy game show the cadets’ hands pointing downward and sideways because they are playing the “circle game,” not pledging their allegiance to white supremacy, you unbelievable idiots.

Amazingly, the United States Naval Academy and United States Military Academy have launched separate investigations into their cadets. The media, meanwhile, are treating the story as though they're near-certain the students flashed "white supremacist" symbols on television.

NBC News, for example, reports that military officials are looking into "what appeared to be white supremacist hand signs" made by students before the Army-Navy football game on Saturday.

Then there is the “Facts First” crowd over at CNN.

“A lot of people saw this as it was happening in real-time," said host John Berman. "Very serious questions."

Erica Hill called the incident, “Troubling.”

Later, host Dave Briggs noted that the Anti-Defamation League “does consider the OK gesture a hate crime in some cases.” Briggs then revealed that CNN would not "show the gesture.”

“Even the notion of it is very disturbing,” said CNN’s Dana Bash.

Then there those in the news media who saved their reactions for Twitter, which is home to just some of the dumbest people alive.

David Johnston, whose Twitter biography boasts of his 53 years of investigative reporting, asked of the West Point and Naval Academy superintendents, “Are you going to discipline the cadets & midshipmen who flashed white power signs at the Army Navy game? Note: video shows they timed their racist hand signals to make sure they’d appear on the Jumbotron. Expulsion?”

“White power symbols,” said NFL columnist Mike Freeman. “From Army cadets. Knowing they are on live television. Trump emboldens this trash. He absolutely does. These guys should be kicked out immediately.”

Another sportswriter, Nathan Bernhardt, expressed irritation that anyone would suggest that the cadets had not actually flashed symbols of white supremacy, writing, "are we all still doing that 'oh they're only throwing up that sign because YOU think it's associated with white supremacy, don't let them troll you' thing or have people grown up.”

“Whatever it used to mean,” said CNN contributing opinion writer Jeff Yang, “this symbol used in this fashion is now indelibly associated with white supremacist individuals and agendas, and these cadets are making it on national TV, behind the head of a cadet of color.”

Put another way: Even if they didn't mean it, they're still guilty.

In January, newsrooms rushed to accuse a group of Covington Catholic students of racism when an abbreviated video of the teenagers' confrontation with an elderly Native American protester went viral. It turns out the students were innocent and that they did none of the things of which they were accused. It has not even been one year, and the exact same story is playing out all over again with the media blindly rushing to accuse obscure nobodies of overt bigotry. The only things that have changed between the January incident and now are the names and locations.
Photo Caption:Army defensive back Caleb McNeill carries the flag of France onto the field before an NCAA college football game against Tulane, Saturday, Nov. 14, 2015, in West Point, N.Y. (AP Photo/Mike Groll)

Materia: College football; Students; News media; White supremacists

Lugar: United States--US New York France

Empresa/organización: Nombre: New York Times Co; NAICS: 511110, 511120, 515112, 515120; Nombre: National Collegiate Athletic Association--NCAA; NAICS: 813990; Nombre: CNN; NAICS: 515210; Nombre: National Football League--NFL; NAICS: 711211, 813990; No mbre: NBC News Channel; NAICS: 515120; Nombre: Anti-Defamation League; NAICS: 813311

Cerdos salvajes amenazan al norte de Estados Unidos

Información de publicación: La Prensa ; Longwood, Fla. [Longwood, Fla]. 16 Dec 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/cerdos-salvajes-amenazan-al-norte-de-estados/docview/2327134309/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Cerdos+salvajes+amenazan+al+norte+de+Estados+Unidos%3A+El+gobierno+responder%26iacute%3Ba+con+un+ataque+a%26eacute%3Breo+a+una+masiva+invasi%26oacute%3Bn+de+los+porcinos&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-12-16&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=La+Prensa&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Ahispanicnews_

Texto completo: Residentes del norte de Estados Unidos empiezan a vivir en carne propia la pesadilla que padecen miles estadounidenses en el sur del país: los cerdos salvajes .
Un reporte del New York Times indica que manadas de especie invasiva, que es común en Texas y otros estados del sur, estarían llegando a los estados del norte desde Canadá.
Relacionado: Cerdos salvajes destruyen cargamento de cocaína escondido en un bosque
El animal es temido por su capacidad destructora. Las noticias de los cerdos acabando con la grama de parques o cultivos en granjas son pan de cada día. Representan pérdidas por un valor cercano a los $2,000 millones de dólares anuales .
“Los cerdos salvajes son destructivos de muchas maneras, impactan varios sectores”, dijo al diario neoyorquino Dale Nolte, en referencia al daño que pueden hacer en las poblaciones de aves, anfibios y reptiles .
Los animales son descendientes de los jabalíes que trajeron los conquistadores europeos , quienes los usaban para tener presas de caza y alimentarse. Con el paso del tiempo se mezclaron con los cerdos de granjas que se escapaban.
El reporte dice que los animales han sido llevados por humanos desde Texas a otros estados con el fin de estimular a los cazadores. El problema es que son especies bastante prolíficas. Una hembra puede tener dos partos de seis crías por año.
En Canadá también fueron traídos para la caza en la década de los ochenta. Se creyó que no iban a resistir el invierno, pero expertos comprobaron que los cerdos aprendieron a hacer madrigueras para aislarse del frío. Otros han desarrollado pieles gruesas.
El gobierno de Estados Unidos hace seguimiento a la situación en la frontera norte y respondería con un ataque aéreo contra los animales.
Los cerdos son portadores de al menos 33 enfermedades , entre ellas la tuberculosis bovina. A los animales se les culpa de los brotes de E. Coli en lechuga y espinaca ya que los cerdos estarían defecando en las granjas.
Crédito: Redacción

Reports: Van Drew to become Republican

Autor: Larsen, Erik. 

Información de publicación: Courier Post ; Cherry Hill, N.J. [Cherry Hill, N.J]. 16 Dec 2019: A.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/reports-van-drew-become-republican/docview/2326774269/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Reports%3A+Van+Drew+to+become+Republican&amp;author=Larsen%2C+Erik&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;date=2019-12-16&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Courier+Post&amp;issn=1050-432X&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: U.S. Rep. Jeff Van Drew, Democrat who was elected in last year's "blue wave" in South Jersey's Second Congressional District, plans to switch parties and become a Republican, according to multiple national news organizations.
The New York Times reported Saturday afternoon that Van Drew, a moderate Democrat who is opposed to the impeachment of President Donald Trump, "told aides on Saturday that he is planning to switch parties and declare himself a Republican as soon as next week, just as the House is casting its historic votes on articles of impeachment."
A former state legislator, Van Drew, 66, of Dennis Township in Cape May, was elected in the November 2018 midterms which resulted in the defeat of every Republican for federal office but U.S. Rep. Chris Smith, who was left as the lone GOP member of New Jersey's congressional delegation earlier this year.
Van Drew's district includes all of Cape May, Atlantic, Cumberland and Salem counties, parts of Burlington, Camden and Gloucester counties and a portion of southern Ocean County.
He succeeded U.S. Rep. Frank LoBiondo, a Republican who had served in the U.S. House of Representatives for 24 years before he retired with the last election.
Politico reported Saturday Van Drew was one of two Democrats who voted against opening the impeachment inquiry and that he remained against the effort, even as the House prepares to vote on articles of impeachment next week.
"The stunning move comes amid new polling that shows Van Drew's approval ratings are under water with Democratic voters in his district," Politico reported. "According to a survey conducted between Dec. 7 and Dec. 10, just 24 percent of respondents think he deserves to be reelected, while 60 percent said they want someone new to represent them."
The New York Times and Politico both reported that Van Drew went to see Trump at the White House on Friday.
The congressman "sought Trump's blessing for the move, which could be critical to his ability to avoid a primary challenge next year, and the president urged him to make the jump, according to two Democrats and one Republican who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to disclose the talks," the Times reported.
Gov. Phil Murphy slammed the congressman in a series of tweets on Saturday night, writing that Van Drew "has chosen his political career over our Constitution. Despite knowing full well that the President has abused the powers of his office, he's now willing to enable Donald Trump just to try to salvage his own election."
Ocean County Freeholder Director Virginia E. Haines, who is also a member of the Republican National Committee, said she was not aware of Van Drew's plans to become a Republican, but that she was not surprised.
Haines said that because Van Drew could not support the march of his caucus toward impeachment, as a Democrat, he would have alienated his party's base going into an election year and energized Republican support for a challenger in a congressional district that already leans Republican.
Erik Larsen: 732-682-9359 or elarsen@gannettnj.com

Sarah Broom remembers Hurricane Katrina in "The Yellow House"

Información de publicación: Wyoming Tribune - Eagle ; Cheyenne, Wyo. [Cheyenne, Wyo]. 15 Dec 2019: 2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/sarah-broom-remembers-hurricane-katrina-yellow/docview/2376098073/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Sarah+Broom+remembers+Hurricane+Katrina+in+%26quot%3BThe+Yellow+House%26quot%3B&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=2&amp;date=2019-12-15&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Wyoming+Tribune+-+Eagle&amp;issn=1075-783X&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anorthcentralnews_

Texto completo: One of the most striking moments in Sarah M. Broom's enthralling memoir, "The Yellow House," comes near its end. Broom's indomitable mother, Ivory Mae Broom, was born and raised in New Orleans, as were her 12 children. Broom describes Ivory Mae staying overnight in her daughter's apartment in the city's iconic French Quarter: "'I'm seventy-one,' she announced from the balcony the day after I moved in. 'And this is the first time I'm sleeping in the French Quarter.'"
If, like many visitors, you think the French Quarter is New Orleans, Broom has another story to tell you. It is a rich and deep one, not just the story of her own life (though that is a rich enough tale) but the story of several generations of her family and of the city that is indelibly their home, both before and after what Broom calls the Water.
The Water, of course, is Hurricane Katrina, the devastating storm that inundated the city in 2005, and from which it has not fully recovered. The French Quarter had minimal damage, but some neighborhoods, like New Orleans East, the site of the Broom family home that gives the book its title, were all but erased from the map.
New Orleans East, Broom tells us, often didn't show up on maps of the city even before Katrina. Wedged between the Industrial Canal, the Intracoastal Waterway and Lake Pontchartrain, it's the newest part of one of the oldest U.S. cities, hopefully promoted as suburbs in the 1960s. Ivory Mae bought her shotgun house on Wilson Avenue in 1961 for $3,200, when she was a 19-year-old widow. (Her first husband was hit by a car as he walked along a road near the Army base where he was stationed.) She had two children and another on the way.
The house needed work; by the time Ivory Mae moved in three years later, she had married her second husband, Simon Broom Sr. Each of them had three children from first marriages, and they would have six together. Sarah is the youngest, born 30 years after her oldest sibling.
She begins the book long before her own arrival, recounting the lives of her siblings, parents, grandparents and great-grandparents. Throughout the book, that family history is interwoven with the history of New Orleans East, which goes from an integrated suburb to a largely black neighborhood that was already beginning to turn into an industrial district before the Water.
Broom writes lovingly but unsentimentally about her family's complex relationships. Ivory Mae is for years a devoted stay-at-home mom, a meticulous housekeeper and fine cook who sews all the clothes for her family. Simon works in the maintenance department at the nearby NASA installation and is as devoted to their family as Ivory Mae is.
But six months after Sarah is born, Simon dies at 56 of an aneurysm, leaving Ivory Mae a widow for the second time at 39. Some of her children will go to college, others will go to prison. Over time, the Yellow House she was so proud of will deteriorate, with too little money or time to make repairs.
And then, the Water. By 2005 Broom was living in Harlem, working as a journalist. About half of her family still lived in New Orleans, and most, including Ivory Mae, fled the storm, in three different directions.
But Sarah's brother Carl would stay in the Yellow House as it drowned, armed with an ax to chop his way out when the attic flooded. He perched on the roof with his two Pekingese dogs, occasionally swimming down the street to check on other stranded residents, until rescuers arrived seven days after the flood.
Broom writes movingly about how her siblings reach out to help each other and their mother, and about the traumas that don't entirely heal. Their grandmother dies not long after the storm, and few people come to her funeral because the family is unable to put an obituary in the Times-Picayune; they make dozens of phone calls but in the flood's wake, "the line stayed busy; no one ever answered."
Broom, too, has a dramatic emotional response, even though she was far away from the storm. She quits her magazine job and goes to Burundi (a sort of African New Orleans East that few Americans can readily locate) to work for a nonprofit for several months.
Then she jumps back into New Orleans with both feet, working as a speechwriter for Mayor Ray Nagin during storm recovery. She ping-pongs back to New York, then to that apartment in the French Quarter, sandwiched between former residences of Tennessee Williams and William Faulkner, still wrestling with her own identity.
Along the way, Ivory Mae struggles with mountains of paperwork to try to repair and return to her beloved Yellow House, but it will meet a melancholy fate.
Broom's writing has appeared in the New Yorker, Oxford American, O magazine and the New York Times Magazine. This memoir is her first book; in November it won the National Book Award for nonfiction.
"The Yellow House" is the story of a uniquely American family and a uniquely American city, beautifully told.

Trump 'Merry Christmas' rally to take place in Battle Creek

Autor: Durnbaugh, Elena. 

Información de publicación: Battle Creek Enquirer ; Battle Creek, Mich. [Battle Creek, Mich]. 15 Dec 2019: N.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/trump-merry-christmas-rally-take-place-battle/docview/2326416164/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Trump+%27Merry+Christmas%27+rally+to+take+place+in+Battle+Creek&amp;author=Durnbaugh%2C+Elena&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=N.1&amp;date=2019-12-15&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Battle+Creek+Enquirer&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: President Donald Trump will host a "Merry Christmas" rally at Kellogg Arena in Battle Creek later this month.
"Michigan is booming thanks to President Trump, and jobs are coming back to the state," Kayleigh McEnany, national press secretary for Donald J. Trump for President, Inc., said in a press release. "President Trump is delivering on his promises, and he looks forward to celebrating those successes with the great men and women of Michigan this Christmas season."
Chairman of the Calhoun County Republican Committee Jeannie Burchfield said the local Republican party was beyond thrilled" to have Trump visit.
"Calhoun County is Trump country, for sure..." she said.
"This will be a fantastic way for us to show support for the president."
Burchfield said the news about the rally was particularly exciting after having Marc Lotter, director of strategic communications for the Trump campaign, speak at the committee's annual dinner on Tuesday and seeing Vice President Mike Pence in Portage on Wednesday.
"This has been a crazy, wonderful week," she said.
Calhoun County Commissioner Jake Smith, a Democrat, said he hoped other presidential candidates would make Battle Creek a campaign stop.
"The Cereal City is where it's at, and I hope the Democratic candidate will come on through, too," he said. "I'm glad Battle Creek is getting the attention."
Despite the Trump administration's claim that Michigan's economy is booming, job growth has slowed considerably since the state's rebound from the Great Recession and has been essentially flat this year, said Charles Ballard, a Michigan State University economics professor and an expert on the state's economy.
That's true for the Upper Midwest, as a whole, according to the latest federal data, he said.
"It doesn't sound to me that our economy is booming," Ballard said. "I don't think we're in a recession, but we're kind of on the edge of a recession.
"The number of jobs is still well below what it was at its peak in 2000."
Trump won Michigan by 10,704 votes in 2016, less than 1% of the 4.8 million votes cast, but recent Sienna College / New York Times Upshot polls show him trailing Democratic candidates Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders here in head-to-head matchups but ahead of Elizabeth Warren.
Trump has visited Michigan several times since the 2016 election, including a rally in December, 2016 in Walker and a visit to the American Center for Mobility at Willow Run in Ypsilanti in March of 2017.
His last visit to the state was April 2018, when he held a rally in Macomb County's Washington Township.
The rally will be held at 7 p.m. on Dec. 18.
Tickets are available online at donaldjtrump.com/events/ battle-creek-mi-dec-christmas-rally. They will be given out on a first-come, first served basis and are limited to two per mobile phone number.
Detroit Free Press reporter Kathleen Gray and Lansing State Journal reporter Ken Palmer contributed to this report.
Contact Elena Durnbaugh at (269) 243-5938 or edurnbaugh@battlecreekenquirer.com.

Your guide to all 'The Nutcrackers' in Phoenix

Autor: Lengel, Kerry. 

Información de publicación: Arizona Republic ; Phoenix, Ariz. [Phoenix, Ariz]. 15 Dec 2019: C.3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/your-guide-all-nutcrackers-phoenix/docview/2326387792/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Your+guide+to+all+%27The+Nutcrackers%27+in+Phoenix&amp;author=Lengel%2C+Kerry&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.3&amp;date=2019-12-15&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Arizona+Republic&amp;issn=0892-8711&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: You don't have to be a ballet lover to love "The Nutcracker." The classical Russian ballet became an American holiday tradition in the 1950s and '60s, and if you've ever accompanied a 6-year-old to a performance, you understand why.
The story is as simple as it gets. A girl gets a gift on Christmas Eve. She falls asleep. She dreams a magical adventure with a handsome prince. She wakes up, but the sense of wonder remains.
Yes, it can be old-fashioned, but the combination of cartoonish whimsy and physical grace that seems to defy the laws of physics is pure magic, and Tchaikovsky's music is irresistibly cheerful.
Here are six ways to introduce youngsters to "The Nutcracker" in metro Phoenix.
1. Ballet Arizona Ballet Arizona spent $1.8 million in 2006 dollars on this lavish staging by acclaimed choreographer Ib Andersen, and it was named one of the three best regional productions in the country by the New York Times. Highlights include the Snow Queen scene, with dancers moving through a cyclone of snowflakes against a nighttime skyscape lit up with gleaming crystals. Modern twists include humorous nods to pop culture. Tickets can be spendy, though. Be sure to search for discount options such as goldstar.com.
Details: Dec. 13-24. Symphony Hall, 75 N. Second St., Phoenix. $39 and up. 602-381-1096, balletaz.org.
2. Phoenix Ballet Led by Slawomir Wozniak, a former principal dancer for the National Opera in his native Poland, Phoenix Ballet is basically a pro-am company, pairing top student talent from Wozniak's Master Ballet Academy with professional ringers. The overall feel is pretty traditional, but the production values are high and the choreography (punctuated by the occasional acrobatic run) is fun and modern.
Details: Dec. 12-23. Orpheum Theatre, 203 W. Adams St., Phoenix. $25-$90. 602-996-8000, phoenixballet.org.
3. Ballet schools There are, of course, many student performances around the Valley, including at public schools. It's the biggest showcase of the year for dance academies such as Ballet Etudes, which is notching its 33rd annual production. Here's a sampling of local ballet schools. You can search online for others.
Southwest Ballet Theatre: Dec. 12-15. Estrella Mountain Community College Performing Arts Center, 3000 N. Dysart Road, Avondale. $18-$24. southwestballettheatre.org.
Southwest Youth Ballet: Dec. 13-15. Higley Center for the Performing Arts, 4132 E. Pecos Road, Gilbert. $10-$30. 480-279-7194, higleycenter.org.
Ahwatukee Foothills Ballet: Dec. 14-15. Desert Vista Fine Arts Theatre, 16440 S. 32nd St., Phoenix. $20-$40. afnutcracker.com.
Ballet Etudes: Dec. 14-22. Mesa Arts Center, 1 E. Main St. $28-$32. 480-644-6500, mesaartscenter.com.
4. 'Marie's Reverie' Speaking of grass roots, Glendale's Brelby Theatre Company is a mom-and-pop shop (Shelby and Brian Maticic built their own theater in a big old house) that makes the most of its modest budget. They also serve up original shows, including this "dance-infused fantasy play" that mashes up "The Nutcracker" and Hans Christian Andersen's "Snow Queen."
Details: Through Dec. 21. Brelby Playhouse, 7154 N. 58th Drive, Glendale. $20-$25. 623-282-2781, brelby.com.
5. At the movies: Bolshoi Ballet Founded the same year as the U.S.A. (1776), the Bolshoi is the most famous ballet company in the world, and its "Nutcracker" comes to movie theaters Sunday, Dec. 15. An encore screening of a live performance, it features dancer principal Semyon Chudin and Margarita Shrainer, who went from understudy to prima ballerina practically overnight.
Details: 12:55 p.m. Sunday. Dec. 15. Find locations at fathomevents.com.
6. Streaming on Netflix, Amazon Prime Finally, you can find several versions of "The Nutcracker" on streaming video services. Netflix has Disney's "The Nutcracker and the Four Realms" (kind of a generic fantasy, but with a mini-ballet featuring a cameo by Misty Copeland), but for the real thing, Amazon Prime has the most offer, including a 1977 TV performance with Mikhail Baryshnikov and a 1986 staging with designs by Maurice Sendak.
Talk to the writer at kerry.lengel@arizonarepublic.com
Phoenix Ballet artistic director Slawomir Wozniak oversees rehearsals at Master Ballet Academy in Scottsdale.
Kerry Lengel/The Republic

PRIVATE EQUITY INDUSTRY: Beware of populist business analysis

Autor: McCoy, Shawn. 

Información de publicación: The Atlanta Journal - Constitution ; Atlanta, Ga. [Atlanta, Ga]. 15 Dec 2019: A.26.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/private-equity-industry-beware-populist-business/docview/2326362153/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=PRIVATE+EQUITY+INDUSTRY%3A+Beware+of+populist+business+analysis&amp;author=McCoy%2C+Shawn&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.26&amp;date=2019-12-15&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Atlanta+Journal+-+Constitution&amp;issn=1539-7459&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: When U.S. Sen. Elizabeth Warren released her plan to rein in Wall Street earlier this year, she said she wanted to stop investors from "bleeding the company dry and walking away enriched even as the company succumbs."
Warren, of course, leans to the far left and has been on the attack against Big Business for years. But conservatives voice similar concerns. In a segment last week, Fox News host Tucker Carlson lambasted a model of "ruthless economic efficiency: Buy a distressed company, outsource the jobs, liquidate the valuable assets, fire middle management, and once the smoke has cleared, dump what remains to the highest bidder, often in Asia."
While Warren and Carlson are correct to worry about the excesses of business -- and there are bad actors -- populist CliffsNotes about business overlook some of the major reasons business decisions are made.
Warren cherry picks a few examples of where private equity investors have failed to turn around struggling companies, and her solution is to change the tax code and force partners and investors to be liable for debt and pension costs -- measures that threaten the entire existence of the private equity industry.
But private equity is an overall positive for the economy, often serving as a last resort to save struggling companies that could otherwise shut down entirely.
Research has shown that private equity-backed businesses were better equipped to weather the last financial crisis. Another recent study demonstrated that while jobs are often lost in the immediate aftermath of a private equity acquisition, companies eventually add jobs and increase productivity.
Meanwhile, Carlson's TV segment focused on outdoor retailer Cabela's. He blames a hedge fund, Elliott Management, for wrecking the company and destroying the small town of Sidney, Nebraska, where Cabela's had its headquarters. Carlson paints Cabela's as a healthy company making $1 billion per year, and if it hadn't been for a hedge fund forcing a merger with rival Bass Pro Shops, the company would have continued its success.
The rosy picture painted doesn't match with reality. In the three years leading up to the sale, Cabela's operating income -- a company's key profitability measure -- was down 24% and falling. The company's founder, Dick Cabela, had passed away in 2014, and the Cabela family was not significantly involved in management. In fact, members of the family had been steadily selling stock on the open market and were already considering the more efficient path of selling the entire company. At the time, a sale was looking increasingly like a good strategic move to keep the company running and maintain as many as possible of its nearly 20,000 jobs.
The sale to Bass Pro was not the best outcome. I wrote in 2016 of the tragedy that would occur if Bass Pro was the buyer. Mergers can create efficiencies and streamline operations, but they can also devastate local communities. In this case, I explained before the sale of Cabela's that merging with Bass Pro Shops would devastate Sidney and cost a town of 6,800 people 2,000 jobs.
What would have presented a better alternative was a sale to a private equity fund. The acquirer would have retooled how the company did business and some jobs would have been lost, but importantly, Sidney would have assumed far less of the burden.
Private equity is often very eager to take over retailers in distress, and while it was doing poorly, Cabela's was healthier than a lot of other retailers seeking private equity buyouts. The big buyout firms should have been eager to put in bids for Cabela's. Many of them had shown interest when Cabela's first began to consider a sale, but that dried up.
Why? Anti-gun sentiment scared them away. According to the New York Times, the New York City employee pension fund was threatening to withdraw its money from any private equity fund that bought Cabela's. This was part of a larger push by anti-gun advocates to divest of any company associated with firearms. Other large public pension funds were likely to follow suit. While Cabela's could have been a profitable investment for private equity, pension funds pulling their capital would have been too costly to bear.
It's unfortunate that gun divestment activists, and anti-private equity politicians for that matter, fail to understand the consequences of their policies. How many guns were taken off the market as a result of New York City's divestment threats? None. Markets will still allocate capital, but that allocation will be less efficient. In this case, Bass Pro was still there to make the purchase. But without the divestment campaign, it is likely that a private equity firm would have purchased Cabela's and preserved jobs in Sidney.
The bigger lesson to consider here is what happens to an economy when politicians try to change how capital is allocated. If Warren forces a massive rollback of the private equity industry, other businesses will face the same fate as Cabela's. Private equity won't be there to buy struggling companies. So instead, less efficient capital allocations will cost jobs and economic growth.
Shawn McCoy is publisher of InsideSources.com.

Join HK kids in protesting Chinese tyranny

Autor: Wilson, Larry. 

Información de publicación: Pasadena Star - News ; Pasadena, Calif. [Pasadena, Calif]. 14 Dec 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/join-hk-kids-protesting-chinese-tyranny/docview/2326534496/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=unknown&amp;atitle=Join+HK+kids+in+protesting+Chinese+tyranny&amp;author=Wilson%2C+Larry&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-12-14&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Pasadena+Star+-+News&amp;issn=1087-3023&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Awestnews_

Texto completo: As the largest protests in weeks rocked Hong Kong last Sunday, with hundreds of thousands filling downtown streets, I was struck by the simple statement from Alice Wong, 24, a biology researcher, a protester among the many in the city’s Victoria Park: “We don’t want to become like China.”
That’s it. Well, she also told a New York Times reporter the obvious intertwined truth in what the mostly young constant demonstrators are after: “We want Hong Kong to continue being Hong Kong.”
That is, she wants her city-state, the former British colony, to continue being culturally Chinese in the broader sense of the diaspora, in the way that Singapore is Chinese — but not; that vast parts of Kuala Lumpur are Chinese — but not; that, well, Arcadia is Chinese — but not.
A heritage, common tongues, an entrepreneurial bent — but without the snooping authoritarian leadership with which the Communist Party has merely replaced the ancient Chinese landlord class in a political system that is anything but communal.
If the plutocrats in Beijing were smart about it, were able to let go of their manic goal of roping all the billions of Chinese peoples in the world into one system, they would realize letting Hong Kong be Hong Kong — letting Taiwan be Taiwan, for that matter — would be by far the best thing for the Mainland as well. That way they don’t have to move toward systems like those in HK and Taipei and Singapore that are mildly democratic, with a few more civil liberties. They can let the broader Chinese nation let off a little steam of freedom without becoming more open themselves.
Instead, the People’s Republic has to control all things in the territories of its growing empire, even if that means putting a million Uighur Muslims in concentration camps.
I wish I could say that it was remotely possible to foresee a successful end game in the Hong Kong kids’ mass marches. But I can’t. As there’s something in a scorpion’s nature that leads it to sting, there’s something in Beijing’s emperors that won’t broach dissent. Sooner or later they’ll send in the People’s Army to put down the actual people.
But it’s not just Chinese people Beijing wants to control. It’s the rest of us, too.
Pasadena lawyer Rob O’Brien, President Trump’s new national security advisor, came back to town last week to speak at a defense forum.
Outside it, he gave an interview to NPR from which I was very happy to find he’s leading the administration’s anti-China world domination wing by detailing the dangers of other nations allowing the Chinese telecommunications company Huawei to build the internet’s new 5G networks:
“So every medical record, every social media post, every email, every financial transaction, and every citizen of the country with cloud computing and artificial intelligence can be sucked up out of Huawei into massive servers in China,” O’Brien told NPR.
Inside the meeting, he kept up the theme, telling defense industry and military officials: “This isn’t a theoretical threat.”
It’s not. And, as if in some over-the-top parody of international bad guys, China’s leaders are coming after your kids, too. TikTok, that latest fad you don’t understand, is the most-downloaded app this year, featuring 15-second videos mostly shared by young people. Here’s how Sen. Josh Hawley, R-Missouri, puts it: “A company compromised by the Chinese Communist Party knows where your children are, knows what they look like, what their voices sound like, what they’re watching and what they share with each other.” If that sounds like a real-life “The Man in the High Castle” world, then I suggest we join the HK kids, and protest.
Larry Wilson is on the Southern California News Group editorial board. lwilson@scng.com.

Court Will Decide if Much of Oklahoma Belongs to the Indians

Autor: Liptak, Adam. 

Información de publicación: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]. 14 Dec 2019: A.17.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/court-will-decide-if-much-oklahoma-belongs/docview/2325679752/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Court+Will+Decide+if+Much+of+Oklahoma+Belongs+to+the+Indians%3A+%5BNational+Desk%5D&amp;author=Liptak%2C+Adam&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.17&amp;date=2019-12-14&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;issn=0362-4331&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anytimes_

Texto completo: The court was poised to decide the question in its last term but appeared to have deadlocked.
The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether much of eastern Oklahoma is an Indian reservation, a question that could have enormous consequences for the area's 1.8 million residents in matters of criminal justice and commerce.
The court tried to resolve the question in a different case in its last term, but it appeared to have deadlocked 4 to 4. Justice Neil M. Gorsuch had recused himself from the case, which was an appeal from a decision of the court on which he once sat, the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, in Denver.
On the last day of the Supreme Court's earlier term, on June 27, the court said it would hear another set of arguments in that case, Sharp v. Murphy, No. 17-1107, in its new term, which started in October.
But that has not happened, and it was not clear that another argument would break the deadlock so long as the court remained short-handed.
The court appears to have decided to hear the new case, McGirt v. Oklahoma, No. 18-9526, an appeal from a state court's decision, to ensure that the issue could be decided by a nine-member court.
The new case concerns Jimcy McGirt, a member of the Muscogee (Creek) Nation who was convicted of sex crimes against a child by state authorities in the Nation's historic boundaries.
Drawing on the 10th Circuit's decision in Patrick Murphy's case, Mr. McGirt argued that only the federal government could prosecute him.
At the argument of Mr. Murphy's case last year, Lisa S. Blatt, a lawyer for the state, said Congress had long ago destroyed the Creek Nation's authority over the land in question, meaning that state prosecutions are proper. She said the Creek Nation's authority had been severely curtailed by the federal government around the time Oklahoma became a state in 1907, incorporating lands that previously had been officially designated as Indian Territory.
Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. said that it was a little late to raise the idea that half of Oklahoma is an Indian reservation.
"There's a fundamental principle of law that derives from Sherlock Holmes, which is the dog that didn't bark," he said. "And how can it be that none of this was recognized by anybody or asserted by the Creek Nation, as far as I'm aware, for 100 years?"
But Ian H. Gershengorn, a lawyer for Mr. Murphy, said the tribe had continued to exercise sovereignty after Oklahoma became a state.
The justices scrutinized the consequences of a ruling in Mr. Murphy's favor. Edwin S. Kneedler, a lawyer for the federal government, arguing in favor of Oklahoma, said they would be vast.
"Any crime involving an Indian as a victim or a perpetrator would be subject to federal jurisdiction, not state jurisdiction," he said. That would, he said, strain the resources of the F.B.I. and federal prosecutors.
The state also would not be able to impose taxes on Native Americans, he added, and many other ordinary laws could be affected.
"This would be a dramatic change from the way everyone has understood it for the past 100 years," Mr. Kneedler said.
Photograph The Supreme Court tried to resolve the question in a different case in its last term, but it appeared to have deadlocked. (PHOTOGRAPH BY Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)
