Deanna impacted community with active involvement in charities

Autor: Boyd, Sara. 

Información de publicación: Green Bay Press Gazette ; Green Bay, Wis. [Green Bay, Wis]. 02 Nov 2019: 208-3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/deanna-impacted-community-with-active-involvement/docview/2311273534/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Deanna+impacted+community+with+active+involvement+in+charities&amp;author=Boyd%2C+Sara&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=208-3&amp;date=2019-11-02&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Green+Bay+Press+Gazette&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo: She's the wife of Green Bay's most famous quarterback, but she's also a force in her own right.
Deanna Favre has inspired thousands with her public battle against breast cancer and helped even more through her charitable work.
"I'd rather not have the cameras on me," Favre said in an interview late last year when she was promoting her book, "Don't Bet Against Me."
But, she acknowledged, "I know that helping people through his (Brett Favre's) notoriety is a gift."
And, help she has.
Deanna Favre learned she had cancer about three years ago.
She subsequently became a spokeswoman for the pink caps campaign that raised more than $1 million to fight breast cancer; more than 200,000 caps were sold.
And last fall, her book, a memoir on surviving breast cancer, hit the New York Times Bestseller's list shortly after its release, inspiring thousands of readers along the way.
Peggy Anderson, of Bloomer, was one of them. She said reading the book helped her cope with the loss of her sister-in-law, who died of breast cancer last July.
"She was an avid Packer fan, considered the angel in the family," she said of her late sister-in-law.
Favre's book has also inspired Anderson to create a line of breast cancer themed scrapbooks, with proceeds going to the Deanna Favre HOPE Foundation.
Deanna's role in the Green Bay community was also significant.
"Deanna was fantastic at being very visible at community events; she had a passion for it," said Mike Daniels, executive vice president of Nicolet Bank and board member of the Favre Fourward Foundation, an organization started by the Favres to raise money for disadvantaged or disabled children in Wisconsin and Mississippi.
Brett Favre's retirement announcement last week means the family will spend most of their time in their hometown of Hattiesburg, Miss. — and Green Bay will lose not one, but two, community icons.
"The community can't help but suffer," Daniels said. "It will unfortunately have an impact on the community."
Mary Ryan, operations manager of the Brown County Library, said Deanna Favre not only helped contribute financially to programs like the Give-A-Kid-A-Book campaign through the Friends of the Library but was active in its growth. Favre was involved in the library program for 11 years, she said.
"We will miss her a great deal, if she doesn't stay involved," she said. "She brought the program to a level it had never seen. It was wonderful. She's just one of the nicest people."
Deanna Favre also helped make the dreams of a baseball league for kids with disabilities come true, said Paul Liegeois, founder and executive director of the Miracle League of Green Bay.
"Deanna and Brett Favre both ... were very instrumental in helping us exceed our expectations," he said. "Deanna herself was so wonderful."
Kelly Mottl, a parent of an autistic son who is a member of the Miracle League, said when Deanna came to the dedication ceremony, she was above and beyond what they expected.
"I couldn't believe how long she stayed, even after her guard-type person tried to get her to go," she said, adding Favre stayed even after it started raining. "I really was impressed with how giving Deanna was of her own time in the lousy weather."
The Favres contributed $100,000 to the Miracle League — with part of it coming from their personal funds — allowing the group to build a concession stand and restroom area, Liegeois said.
"I was personally humbled," he said. "I was flattered to know they would be involved in something like that, and help see my dream project come to fruition."
Hopefully Favre will remain active in the community and continue the great impact she has made on the residents of the Greater Green Bay area, he said.
It's a hope Favre has as well, she said at a Thursday morning press conference where her husband took media questions about his retirement.
"It was very rewarding to be a part of this community and be a part of the charity work going on," she said. "The people here are very appreciative, grateful. I hope that it continues, but I don't think it will be the extent it has been."
Liegeois said Favre's contributions whether through money or visibility have been extraordinary.
"She is such a generous person," he said. "People can relate to her real-life situations and then try to give back to the community the way that she does."
Whatever the charity, or whatever the cause, Daniels said what the Favres contributed to the Green Bay community is something rare.
"The Favres didn't do what they did because they had to, they believed it was the right thing to do. They really believed that giving back to the community where they lived and worked was necessary and important," he said. "It was something they needed to do to make the community a better place."
Deanna Favre, Brett Favre's wife, talks to Howe Elementary School students Nov. 13, 2007, at the Brown County Central Library in downtown Green Bay. Favre helped launch the annual Give-a-Kid-a-Book drive. File/Press-Gazette
Deanna Favre, Brett Favre, middle, and Charles Woodson head to midfield for the coin toss before a game against the Chicago Bears on Oct. 7, 2007. File/Press-Gazette

Running Into the Night, and Traffic

Autor: Gilbertson, Ashley. 

Información de publicación: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]. 02 Nov 2019: B.8.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/running-into-night-traffic/docview/2311159401/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Running+Into+the+Night%2C+and+Traffic%3A+%5BSports+Desk%5D&amp;author=Gilbertson%2C+Ashley&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.8&amp;date=2019-11-02&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;issn=0362-4331&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anytimes_

Texto completo: It's almost midnight in Gowanus and 236 of New York City's fastest runners are lined up in the rain on a dark street. There are runners who have qualified for the Olympic Trials and track champions blocking the way of any vehicle out at that hour, as well as plenty of workaday running enthusiasts.
A garbage truck honks as racers get a briefing: there will be no barricades, no mile markers, no live bands -- we're a renegade band of running freaks on regular city streets.
"Know the route," shouts Joe DiNoto, the founder of Orchard Street Runners. "Keep it clean."
We bolt into the darkness. A construction worker screams as we cut through his work site, under backhoes and around gaping holes. Parts of the course are flooded, and everyone chases the leader, who is holding close to a sub-five-minute mile pace. The puddles being kicked up taste like industrial waste. We are one mile down, and with proper routing, twelve and change left. The infamous Midnight Half is underway.
More than 50,000 runners will take to the streets of New York Sunday, bounding across the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge for a 26.2 mile jaunt through the five boroughs. This midnight half-marathon is not that, but this run and the others I do each Tuesday night with this group offer inspiration that doesn't exist in sanctioned races with their closed courses and participation medals but reveals another running heartbeat of New York. Sometimes there's a little prize money -- $ 100 in a sweaty, crumpled envelope -- but no one is really here for that. The prize is street cred. Being fast isn't enough to take first place.
We have to know the streets, and more important, how they work. Aim for the center point of the approaching car and look beyond it to find a line. Be ready to jump. Watch rear vision mirrors for intent. Never make eye contact with New Yorkers when you're threading through a packed cross walk -- they panic and stop like prey. Never disturb the city's cadence. Use its flow. Find your line.
From a bird's-eye view, New York City appears to be the perfect grid. Planned, ordered, structured. But from our level, down here in the skinny streets between the tall buildings, among the rats and truck exhaust and endless sirens, it's chaos, even in the middle of the night. The world's most ambitious people working, walking, buying, driving, selling, riding -- the hustle -- with no concern for societal niceties. Get the hell out of the way, because their story is more important than yours.
Now throw the runner into the mix: you'll generally find them away from all that, out by the rivers, in the manicured parks, safely tucked away from the madness. Running groups meet at warm stores with doughnuts and coffee, with balloons and pace groups. It's easier.
For some of us, easy isn't what we seek.
We are a group of about two dozen slightly crazy people founded eight years ago by Joe DiNoto, a native New Yorker. Every Tuesday, we meet under a streetlamp on the Lower East Side, a swarm of tattoos, short shorts, and no bag check or small talk and lots of twitching muscles. We arrive armed with a knowledge of the route, posted on Instagram earlier in the day: a simple black and white photograph of the city with a white line snaking through the unmarked streets.
At 8 p.m. sharp, the group silently fans out into the street. The first four hundred meters is always easy, across Canal or Delancey Street, toward a bridge. Misfits amid the traffic, pacing with the cars, dodging pedestrians and cyclists as we blow through lights.
As we approach the bridge, we are rocks in a slingshot, being drawn slowly back, and then we're on it. In it. Breathing quickens, gaits open, the pace snaps. Hang on, I tell myself, but then I find myself out front, hauling a 5:30 pace up the bridge, and all I can hear is the pack of runners on my heel, chasing me down. I hold my phone over my shoulder and shoot some photographs.
We're alone in our pain, though on the best nights, I find myself a part of this swarm. We share a singular focus: that through this exercise of pushing the body to the very edge, we learn about the darkest canyons of our minds.
We aren't the fastest group in the city. We are raw, gritty, the antisocial kids at school, the addicts, the outcasts who found kindred spirits when we moved here. Normal, well-adjusted folks aren't running 240-mile races in the mountains of Utah, or sprinting through traffic against the advice of their loved ones for 14 miles on school nights.
I remember being utterly shattered at the end of a workout with Orchard Street Runners one night. I had failed to stay with the even slower, second group of runners. As I climbed the Manhattan Bridge alone, I was moved to tears by the view of New York. Strange, random things come into your mind when you've successfully crushed your spirit.
It's at this point that I remember why I adore all this. Running is easy. The brutality lies in overcoming the mind, forcing yourself to push beyond what your body claims is possible. 'Ease back', it says, 'it's not a race'. Screw you, I reply, often out loud, and move faster.
When death feels close, I picture Erik Reitinger, the group's captain, explaining his race strategy: "Suicide."
As I wind my way through the city's grid, the elements that can overwhelm start to fall into a system. Masses of people streaming out of offices and into subways, traffic clogging every street and avenue, lines for restaurants and velvet ropes outside bars and pop-up sales, the black S.U.V.s idling outside the banks on Wall Street. I used to find myself angered by it, the selfishness, the meaningless of it all. Now, I've found a rhythm to it. I no longer fight it; I use it.
Ashley Gilbertson is a member of the VII Photo Agency and regularly contributes to The New York Times, ProPublica and Unicef. A permanent exhibition of Ashley Gilbertson's running photographs can be seen at the Fitler Club, 24 S 24th St, Philadelphia.

Participants ran across the Williamsburg Bridge, around the Brooklyn Navy Yard and back to Manhattan. Materia: Running; Photographs; Marathons

Lugar: New York City New York New York Utah New Jersey

When a Big Story Is Not the News

Autor: Barbaro, Michael. 

Información de publicación: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]. 02 Nov 2019: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/when-big-story-is-not-news/docview/2311154826/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=When+a+Big+Story+Is+Not+the+News%3A+%5BNational+Desk%5D&amp;author=Barbaro%2C+Michael&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2019-11-02&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;issn=0362-4331&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anytimes_

Texto completo: A few days ago, a listener named Tiffany wrote in with a suggestion.
"I love 'The Daily' -- great stuff! But why aren't all the episodes now about impeachment? Isn't that all we want to know about?"
A reasonable question. This is a historic moment. In modern American history, there have been only two other congressional votes to open an impeachment inquiry of a sitting president. House impeachment investigators are revealing startling new facts every day. And what began one month ago as a closed-door process is about to become highly public, through a series of open hearings, testimonies, disclosures and, eventually, an investigative report (the subject of today's episode).
We could, as Tiffany proposes, fill five shows a week with everything there is to know, explain and analyze about the impeachment process.
But we're not prepared to do that -- not at this point, anyway. "The Daily" is a news show, but our definition of news has, from the beginning, been deliberately broad. The news is as much what's happening in Syria, or inside the Food and Drug Administration, or within Boeing, as it is inside the U.S. Capitol.
Impeachment is, indisputably, a major story with enormous implications. But, on many days, the individual developments don't deepen or change our understanding of the story enough to fill an entire episode. So we're taking a creative approach to the subject: Our producers Rachel Quester and Clare Toeniskoetter recently spent the week in Washington, turning five days of developments into a single compelling episode.
When important news breaks in the impeachment story, we will put aside whatever we're working on and make a new episode, as we did last week, after a witness delivered what House Democrats called the most damning testimony yet against President Trump.
But this past week, four of our five episodes had nothing to do with impeachment. We examined the public health crisis surrounding vaping in a two-part series; explored the life and death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the founder of ISIS; and investigated what Boeing executives knew about the dangers of the 737 Max, and when they knew it.
As the impeachment inquiry enters an intensive new phase, it will inevitably become the subject of many episodes. Just not every episode.
Talk to Michael on Twitter: @mikiebarb .
______
What we still don't know about vaping
Our producer Alexandra Leigh Young on this week's vaping series, which was in the works for almost a year:
"It appeared on our list of potential episodes last winter, written on the whiteboard: JUUL/ALTRIA. One of the world's largest tobacco companies had invested more than $ 12 billion into the ostensibly anti-tobacco vaping company, and I couldn't get the news out of my head.
"By this spring, the episode idea was still on our list, but it had lost a word along the way. Now it was simply: JUUL. The idea was starting to morph. My younger cousins were telling me about kids who Juuled in the bathrooms at their high school. And suddenly, these mysterious lung illnesses started cropping up all over the country.
"By the end of the summer, vaping-related deaths were in the dozens. A friend said to me, "Yeah, but I don't vape bootleg stuff, so I'm fine." To me, it sounded more like, "I'm going to be O.K., right?" I didn't know what to tell him.
"As my questions grew, I got on the phone with our reporters Julie Bosman and Sheila Kaplan, and we decided we needed two episodes to cover the sprawling narrative. Part 1 would look at the medical mysteries, and Part 2 would tell the story of Juul.
"Two episodes don't feel like enough. This week, we received emails from listeners who, like my friend, wanted more clarification on the links between bootleg products, THC vapes and nicotine vapes. But as we said in the series, this is just the beginning of a public health crisis. The C.D.C. still doesn't know what exactly is causing these illnesses and deaths. And so a new episode idea popped up on my story list this week. It reads: BOOTLEG VAPING."
______
______
What we're watching
Who: Bianca Giaever, audio producer
What: "The Show About the Show," a metadocumentary series
For years I have begged and pleaded with my friends and family to watch my favorite show. "Where do we find it?" They asked me. "Netflix? Hulu?"
"No," I tell them. "The greatest show of our time is sponsored by BRIC TV, a Brooklyn nonprofit. And it's only available on YouTube."
Not very many of my friends have seen it. This week, however, my tiny beloved show was featured in The New York Times Magazine, and I feel like a proud parent. The filmmaker is named Caveh Zahedi. (Disclaimer: I was such a fan of the show that I tracked Caveh down a couple of years ago and befriended him.)
Each episode of "The Show About the Show" is about the making of the previous episode. (You might need to read that sentence a few times.) Imagine reality television, but flawlessly executed by a radically honest performance artist. In the show, Caveh combines camera monologues, documentary footage and re-enactments to chronicle the struggles of everyday life.
"You're gonna have to choose between the show or our family," Caveh's wife eventually says to him in Season 1, when she felt that the show had gone too far. They had been married for 16 years, but Caveh chose the show. Then he documented their breakup.
______
On 'The Daily' this week
Monday: "I think that his death raises an alarming possibility." In Part 1 of our vaping series, Julie Bosman looks at what one man's story tells us about the effect of e-cigarettes.
Tuesday: Rukmini Callimachi on why, after the death of the ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi during a U.S. raid over the weekend, "it feels like we're seeing a replay of 2011 all over again."
Wednesday: Part 2 on Juul: "What they didn't expect, and what nobody expected," Sheila Kaplan tells us, "was all over the country, people would start getting very sick."
Thursday: Boeing's chief executive, Dennis Muilenburg, testified before Congress this week on the two crashes of 737 Max jets. Natalie Kitroeff was there.
Friday: The House of Representatives took its first vote to begin an impeachment inquiry into President Trump. Julie Hirschfeld Davis on what the next phase of the inquiry will look like.

Scout troop a coup for girls

Autor: Monique Welch -- Times. 

Información de publicación: Tampa Bay Times ; Tampa Bay [Tampa Bay]. 01 Nov 2019: 1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/scout-troop-coup-girls/docview/2311762084/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Scout+troop+a+coup+for+girls%3A+The+daughter+of+an+Eagle+Scout+jumped+at+the+chance+to+start+a+female+troop+once+Boy+Scouts+allowed+it&amp;author=Monique+Welch+--+Times&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=1&amp;date=2019-11-01&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Tampa+Bay+Times&amp;issn=2327-9052&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: CLEARWATER  Jamie Bennett never thought in her lifetime that she would see the day when Boy Scouts would admit girls.

But when she heard the change was coming, she jumped on the opportunity to start a female troop before Boy Scouts of America made it official in October 2017.

The historic change after more than 100 years meant girls could now join the Cub Scout program for children ages 5 to 10, and they could achieve the coveted Eagle Scout rank in its older Boy Scouts program, which was changed to Scouts BSA to welcome boys and girls ages 11 to 17.

Bennett, 48, immediately began gathering everything required for approved from the council  a signed charter agreement, at least five youth and adult applications, fees, committee members, and youth protection certificates.

As a daughter of an Eagle Scout, the highest rank, and a mother of three who has been heavily involved in Boy Scouts leadership for 10 years with her two sons, she witnessed its benefits on boys and thought girls deserved the same.

It just makes sense, Bennett said. There are so many life skills that are taught throughout scouting, that it doesnt matter what your gender is.

On Feb. 7, Bennett welcomed 10 girls to the first meeting for Troop 135, one of the first all-female troops in Tampa Bay and the only one of 65 troops in the Miccosukee (North Pinellas County District), at the Heritage United Methodist Church in Clearwater.

The girls program is exactly the same as the boys.

They wear the same tan and olive green uniforms, learn from

the same Scout book, lead their meetings like the boys, and they even meet at the same place, and at the same time. They are just in separate rooms.

There are a few occasions when the two troops unite, such as training and summer camp.

District executive Ryan Cooper anticipates about four more female troops will start in January.

Many others have tried to start a female unit but havent seen success because they either cannot secure a leader, they have trouble recruiting girls at an age when many are already involved in sports, dance, cheerleading or gymnastics, or their charter organizations vetoed the idea of accepting girls into Boy Scouts.

With girls just starting this year, its a tester year even though its official, Cooper said.

Being that they are girls, they have to have a female leader. Thats a national policy. But getting leadership is difficult in itself. Youre asking parents that already have kids, already have jobs, and already have things on their plate to dedicate more time to help run a program. And since the program is new to girls, its harder to find girls to be a part of a program they had no interaction with prior.

But luckily for Bennett, her ties to Boys Scouts paid off.

All but one of her Scouts had brothers in Boys Scouts, so word of mouth, a newsletter announcement, and a Facebook post connected her with girls and their families already interested in joining.

Isabella Fitzpatrick is the one Scout without a brother but still, she is no stranger to Scouting. She frequently heard stories from her father, who is an Eagle Scout, about the program. As someone who loves the outdoors, she was fascinated with his stories about his adventures fishing, woodcarving, and camping.

At the time, she could only dream of recreating some of her fathers experiences.

I always wanted to be a Boy Scout, she said, but I never thought itd be possible.

So instead, Fitzpatrick, 13, joined Girl Scouts. But she left once her family got word of this female troop developing in their area.

Finally, she thought, her dreams would come true.

Fitzpatricks situation highlights a longstanding feud between Girl Scouts U.S.A. and Boy Scouts of America.

According to a 2017 New York Times report, Kathy Hopinkah Hannan, the president of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A., wrote a letter to her counterpart, Randall Stephenson of the Boy Scouts, accusing the organization of trying to undercut the Girl Scouts through a covert campaign to recruit girls. In the letter, Hannan formally requested that they stay focused on serving the 90 percent of American boys not currently participating in Boy Scouts.

The move caused tension between two organizations that once had an amicable relationship.

The tension spread locally, too.

We are going after a different girl, Bennett said. Were going after the girl that wants to be outside, getting her hands dirty, learning outdoor skills, playing with hatchets and knives.

But Jessica Muroff, the CEO of Girl Scouts of West Central Florida, thinks many people have the wrong idea about Girl Scouts.

This is one of the most common misconceptions is that we dont have the same outside activities for girls, she said.

If you put our programs side by side we offer some of the same if not more activities for girls at a younger age.

Some of these programs Muroff references include overnight camping, archery, and high ropes challenge courses that girls can explore beginning in the first grade.

The Girl Scouts and some charter organizations werent the only ones that did not embrace the change.

Bennett said occasionally she had to prepare the girls when they went out in public to ignore rude remarks and confusion.

She remembers taking them out for the first time in their uniforms to sell hot chocolate at Largo Central Parks Christmas Lights celebration and people stared at them, gave them weird looks or said: go join Girl Scouts.

Aside from that, the female unit has received minimal opposition. It just took Bennett explaining to some of the boys parents, who were skeptical at first that it would affect the boys troops, that the troops would be separate.

Troop 135 meets every Thursday to play games, learn key skills from their Scout book and plan activities and camps. They are currently planning a three-day trip to NASA next year.

Contact Monique Welch at mwelch@tampabay.com or Follow mo_unique_.

Trump files to become Palm Beach resident

Autor: Kleinberg, Eliot. 

Información de publicación: Palm Beach Post ; West Palm Beach, Fla. [West Palm Beach, Fla]. 01 Nov 2019: 3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/trump-files-become-palm-beach-resident/docview/2311627725/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Trump+files+to+become+Palm+Beach+resident&amp;author=Kleinberg%2C+Eliot&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=3&amp;date=2019-11-01&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Palm+Beach+Post&amp;issn=1528-5758&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: PALM BEACH — President Donald Trump plans to be a permanent resident of Mar-a-Lago, according to a document he filed this month in Palm Beach County Court.
Trump filed an affidavit Oct. 4 to change his primary domicile to 1100 S. Ocean Blvd., the address of the mansion he converted into a country club and where he's stayed numerous times since his November 2016 election.
The “Declaration of Domicile” form bearing the president's signature was dated Sept. 27 and notarized in Washington, D.C.
It said Mar-a-Lago "constitutes my predominant and principal home, and I intend to continue it permanently as such."
The form says he formerly resided at 721 Fifth Ave. in Manhattan, the address of Trump Tower.
The first lady, Melania Trump, simultaneously filed the same form.
Their documents each list two "other places of abode" — Trump's summer retreat in New Jersey, and the White House. The New York Times first reported on the forms Thursday evening.
A tally shows that since Trump became president, he has spent all or part of 99 days in Palm Beach over 24 visits. He last visited during the Easter holiday in late April and is expected to return for Thanksgiving, as he did in 2018.
He planned a 17-day stay during the 2018-19 Christmas-New Year holidays, but stayed in Washington because of the 35-day federal government shutdown.
Mar-a-Lago — Spanish for "sea to lake" — sits on 17 acres spanning the island from the Atlantic Ocean to the Intracoastal Waterway.
The estate was built Marjorie Merriweather Post, who inherited $11 million from her father, Charles William Post, who built the breakfast cereal empire. She spent $2.5 million in 1920s dollars on the construction.
Completed in 1927, Mar-a-Lago featured 58 bedrooms, 33 bathrooms with gold fixtures, three bomb shelters, an 1,800-square-foot living room (with gold leaf on its 42-foot ceilings), a 1,500-square-foot dining room, a theater, a 75-foot tower, 36,000 antique Spanish tiles and a nine-hole golf course.
In 1964, Post offered Mar-a-Lago to the state, which balked at the $250,000 overhead. When she died in 1973, she willed it to the federal government as a winter White House. The estate remained dormant, and seven years later the government gave it back to Post’s heirs.
In 1985, Trump paid $15 million for the mansion and its furnishings. He restored the home and built a putting green, tennis courts and croquet court, then added a spa, salon and health club.
Bemoaning the massive upkeep, Trump in 1995 converted Mar-a-Lago into a private club. It often rents out space for high-profile charity balls and other galas.

@eliotkpbp

Biden comes in fourth place in Iowa poll as Buttigieg rises

Autor: Larsen, Emily. 

Información de publicación: Washington Examiner ; Washington, D.C. [Washington, D.C]. 01 Nov 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/biden-comes-fourth-place-iowa-poll-as-buttigieg/docview/2311202184/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Biden+comes+in+fourth+place+in+Iowa+poll+as+Buttigieg+rises&amp;author=Larsen%2C+Emily&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-11-01&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Washington+Examiner&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: Joe Biden came in fourth place in a poll of likely Iowa Democratic caucuses voters released Friday, adding to signs that the former vice president and the one-time front-runner is in danger of showing poorly in the first-in-the-nation state nominating contest.
Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren led the field in the New York Times/Siena College Iowa poll released Friday, with 22% support, followed by Vermont Sen. Sanders at 19%, South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg at 18%, and Biden at 17%.
Biden's campaign staff has tempered expectations about him winning Iowa and New Hampshire, the first two nominating contests in the Democratic presidential primary, instead turning focus to South Carolina, where he maintains a lead, and Super Tuesday states. Iowa officials who have endorsed Biden are worried about his campaign's attitude toward the state and cite the state director not living Iowa as one reason for his fragile position in the race.
The poll pushed Biden to third place in the RealClearPolitics average of primary polls in Iowa, which finds Warren at 22.3%, Buttigieg at 17%, Biden at 15.7%, and Sanders at 15.3%. Biden led in the average by up to 10.5 points through mid-September, but then Warren began to pass him in many polls.
Meanwhile, Buttigieg has emerged as a prominent alternative to Biden for Democrats uncomfortable with ultra-progressive Sanders or Warren leading the ticket in 2020 as Biden's flailing in the polls and lackluster fundraising sparks worries about whether Biden is electable enough to beat President Trump.
The poll also spells trouble for California Sen. Kamala Harris, who this week laid off many of her national campaign staff and redirected attention and resources to Iowa. She got 3% support in the poll, tied for sixth place with tech entrepreneur Andrew Yang. Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar was in fifth place with 4% support.
Friday's poll is the first Iowa poll conducted by New York Times/Siena College in the 2020 Democratic primary. It surveyed 439 likely Democratic caucus voters in Iowa from Oct. 25-30 and has a margin of error of 4.7 points.

Trump becomes ‘Florida Man’ after declaring Mar-a-Lago his permanent residence

Autor: Brest, Mike. 

Información de publicación: Washington Examiner ; Washington, D.C. [Washington, D.C]. 01 Nov 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/trump-becomes-florida-man-after-declaring-mar/docview/2311202023/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Trump+becomes+%26lsquo%3BFlorida+Man%26rsquo%3B+after+declaring+Mar-a-Lago+his+permanent+residence&amp;author=Brest%2C+Mike&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-11-01&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Washington+Examiner&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: President Trump legally changed his primary residence from New York, where he's spent most of his life, to Florida back in September.
The president and first lady both filed a "declaration of domicile," saying that their Mar-a-Lago club, their resort in West Palm Beach, Florida, will be their permanent residence, the New York Times first reported.
Trump said on Twitter that he "cherish[es] New York" and the people but pointed to paying "millions of dollars in city, state and local taxes each year" and being "treated very badly by the political leaders" as the reason behind his move.TweetTrump's change in residence is not expected to affect the subpoena filed by Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney, meant to obtain the president's tax returns. Trump has attempted to thwart Vance Jr.'s investigation with a federal lawsuit.
The move could keep more money in Trump's pockets because Florida does not have a state income tax or inheritance tax.
Throughout the first three years of his presidency, Trump has spent 99 days at his Mar-a-Lago resort compared to 20 days at Trump Tower, his New York residence, according to NBC News.
Following the news, many took to social media to comment on the president's residency switch.Tweet

Materia: Presidents; First ladies

'Whiteness'

Información de publicación: Washington Examiner ; Washington, D.C. [Washington, D.C]. 31 Oct 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/whiteness/docview/2310952180/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=%27Whiteness%27&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-10-31&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Washington+Examiner&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: I have observed with a sort of low-grade alarm the evolution of the woke usages of the word “white.” Notable notches on the timeline include the old, semi-ironic use of “that’s so white” to mean so square, which at some point melted into constant acknowledgments and only-sometimes-instructive invocations of “white privilege.” And then “white” accrued a suffix, leading to the abstract noun “whiteness.” A little while back, if you hung around a certain class of overeducated people, some instances of white privilege might be held up along with the instruction to “watch whiteness work.”
So, casual anti-white racism is a core part of the radical chic verbal fashion sense. Fine. As far as it goes, this is not some horrible racial injustice against whites. White Americans are not in any serious danger of being laid low by organized prejudice. I’m white, and I’m certainly not put out by it. My only practical concern here is that the cultural conversation at large emphasizing white identity might cause certain kinds of bitter and vulnerable white people to emphasize their white identity with tattoos and torches and such. Really not a fan of that.
The latest evolution in wording whiteness, however, alarmed me more seriously. In a New York Times article titled “A Racist Attack Shows How Whiteness Evolves,” Dr. Nell Irvin Painter, author of The History of White People, has turned “white” into, as my second-grade teacher taught me to describe verbs, an “action word.” He describes a racist attack in New Jersey in which two boys of Indian descent allegedly attacked four African American girls while using racial slurs.
This is horrible, but it does not really raise any scholarly questions. Painter disagrees. He finds in it an opportunity for some racial theorizing about the essence of what race, and specifically whiteness, is: “Instead of asking what the boys’ reported racial identity tells us about the nature of the attack, we should see the boys as enacting American whiteness through anti-black assault in a very traditional way. In doing so, the assailants are demonstrating how race is a social construct that people make through their actions. They show race in the making, and show how race is something we perform, not just something we are in our blood or in the color of our skin.”
The verb-phrase “enacting whiteness” is such an academese syntactical abomination that I struggle to type it. I suppose he couldn’t have gone with “whitening” because of the dental meaning, but really. Painter, scamming at the level of Tom Sawyer doing some whitewashing, is trying to argue that to be white is to be racist, and that to be racist is to be white. Is a white person who is not presently in the middle of being racist against black people not, in that moment, white, since said honky is not “enacting whiteness” just then? Seems questionable. But, invoking a “traditional black/white binary” that we have to find a way to fit everyone into, Painter suggests “we should observe their actions. Or how they perform race.”
Well, somebody here is performing. All I can reply is that if your idea of whiteness includes nonwhite people, you’ve thought about this a creepy amount, and it has broken your common sense. Take a step back. Don’t watch whiteness work. Watch TV or something.

Materia: Racial identity; Racism; Race

Lugar: New York New Jersey

Empresa/organización: Nombre: New York Times Co; NAICS: 511110, 511120, 515112, 515120

Dreamer lucha para que su madre enferma de cáncer no sea deportada

Información de publicación: El Diario La Prensa ; New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]. 31 Oct 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/dreamer-lucha-para-que-su-madre-enferma-de-cáncer/docview/2310809148/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Dreamer+lucha+para+que+su+madre+enferma+de+c%26aacute%3Bncer+no+sea+deportada%3A+%26quot%3BMe+gui%26oacute%3B%2C+trabaj%26oacute%3B+en+tres+empleos+para+mantenerme.+Mi+madre+es+la+raz%26oacute%3Bn+por+la+que+voy+a+la+Universidad+de+Yale%26quot%3B&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-10-31&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=El+Diario+La+Prensa&amp;issn=0742-9428&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Ahispanicnews_

Texto completo: Un Dreamer lucha para frenar la deportación de su madre, una paciente de cáncer en etapa cuatro.
De acuerdo con New York Times, la hondureña Tania Romero se encuentra bajo custodia de ICE después de ser detenida en el tráfico en el condado de Gwinnett en Georgia . La mujer tenía orden de deportación desde 2008 por no asistir a sus audiencias en una orden de inmigración.
Sin embargo, su hijo Cristian Padilla Romero probó que la mujer de 48 años nunca recibió las citaciones. Los sobres fueron devueltos a ICE por el Servicio Postal del Estados Unidos .
El joven es un estudiante de doctorado en la prestigiosa Universidad de Yale. Desde allí ha promovido una campaña para frenar la deportación de su madre y costear los gastos médicos de su tratamiento para el cáncer oral.
Relacionado: Pequeño detalle lo salvó de la deportación y le dio la residencia. Pero ahora le pedían $100,000
“Me guió, trabajó en tres empleos para mantenerme”, dijo Padilla, quien llegó a Estados Unidos a los siete años, al Times. “Mi madre es la principal razón por la que voy a Yale”.
El inmigrante, que también es indocumentado pero protegido por el DACA, también ha denunciado que su madre no ha recibido la atención médica que su madre requiere en este momento.
Romero cruzó la frontera ilegalmente hace unos 20 años . Ha trabajado limpiando casas, lavando platos y en construcción.
ICE dijo al Times que por privacidad no puede hablar del caso.
La campaña en GoFundMe para ayudar a los Romero la puedes encontrar aquí.
Crédito: Redacción

Lugar: New York Georgia

Empresa/organización: Nombre: New York Times Co; NAICS: 511110, 511120, 515112, 515120; Nombre: GoFundMe; NAICS: 518210

3 BILLION FEWER BIRDS

Autor: Steecker, Matt. 

Información de publicación: Press & Sun-Bulletin ; Binghamton, N.Y. [Binghamton, N.Y]. 31 Oct 2019: A.7.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/3-billion-fewer-birds/docview/2310784132/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=3+BILLION+FEWER+BIRDS%3A+HOW+S.+TIER+HELPED+PUBLISH+LANDMARK+STUDY&amp;author=Steecker%2C+Matt&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.7&amp;date=2019-10-31&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Press+%26+Sun-Bulletin&amp;issn=0886-8816&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: "It was a shock at first, but maybe we should not have been surprised."
Ken Rosenberg
Applied conservation scientist, Cornell University
"The U.S. has a very large network of radars that cover ... anything in the sky — not just weather, but also wildlife. Birds give strong signals. More and more have realized this, and it's an important data source for biologists. If you look at it on your iPhone, you don't see the individual bird, but a blob of bio-life moving. That's what is used for birds."
Adriaan Dokter, a research associate at Cornell
When a team of Cornell University researchers and others published a bird study in the online journal Science on Sept. 19, they didn't expect the worldwide reaction that followed.
The findings: North America has lost 2.9 billion birds in the past 50 years — 29% of the avian population.
The impact: An ecosystem is losing a key component and it's a sign of a quickly changing environment that will affect other wildlife, plants and more.
The spotlight: Once the study was released, the New York Times picked up the story and highlighted a startling statement from David Yarnold, president and chief executive of the National Audubon Society, who called the findings "a full-blown crisis." Other major media outlets picked up the story, and conservationists around the world were shocked and inspired to take action.
"The reaction to the study has been phenomenal. We were hoping for a big response," said Ken Rosenberg, an applied conservation scientist at Cornell, the study's lead author and a leader of research and planning on joint initiatives by the Cornell Lab of Ornithology Lab and the American Bird Conservancy.
"We expected some response, but this is the biggest thing we've seen for a bird paper. It was amazing to see the findings on the front page of the New York Times and the Washington Post. All of networks talking birds for one day was so great. The trick now is how to keep the interest and keep the momentum going so it is not a headline that disappears."
From Ithaca and beyond To publish the study, the team of scientists tracked birds for decades, and parts of the study came from Ithaca's backyards and skies, as countless passionate non-professional bird-watchers submitted their observations to databases and helped carry out studies of bird populations every year.
Some of the most fascinating parts of the study came from weather radar maps as the researches found some types of birds were declining in population, but others, such as waterfowl and raptors, were increasing in numbers.
"It was quite overwhelming," said Adriaan Dokter, a research associate at Cornell. "It reached Europe, too. It went all over the world. It was more than what we expected."
Dokter noted he and Rosenberg were interviewed by Australian, Dutch and Spanish media.
"People see this trend not just here, but in Europe," Dokter said. "It's not just a local U.S. phenomenon, but a trend all over the world."
To Dokter, the confirmation of the population decrease across hundreds of bird species is like a canary in a coal mine.
"It's a decrease in the vitality of the ecosystem that we see. Birds depend on insects. Insects are important to the ecosystem of plants," he said. "It means something fundamental in our environment ... It's a warning sign that we have to be careful. Things are rapidly changing."
How scientists researched the decline in birds Surveying: Scientists and amateurs observed birds to complete censuses.
Weather radar: Scientists examined weather radar maps to determine the cumulative weight of birds in the sky.
Research: Researchers examined hundreds of different surveys.
Analysis: After finding the best data from the surveys, scientists conducted statistical analyses to determine how much populations have decreased.
The team at Cornell partnered with the American Bird Conservancy, National Audubon Society, Bird Conservancy of the Rockies, Canadian Wildlife Service, the Georgetown University Georgetown Environment Initiative, United States Geological Survey and the Smithsonian National Zoological Park Conservation Biology Institute.
"'Were there declines or shifts?'" Rosenberg said about the questions researchers had years ago. "Someone never did this comprehensive work."
Researchers then obtained answers they were searching for — there's been an overall decline in the bird population, and the largest declines have been in the most common species.
"It was a shock at first, but maybe we should not have been surprised," Rosenberg said.
Using weather radar, Dokter was able to pick up the cumulative weights of birds migrating, which he later analyzed. The birds he researched tended to be long-distance migratory birds, which contribute more to the bio-life on radar maps.
"The U.S. has a very large network of radars that cover ... anything in the sky — not just weather, but also wildlife," Dokter said. "Birds give strong signals. More and more have realized this, and it's an important data source for biologists. If you look at it on your iPhone, you don't see the individual bird, but a blob of bio-life moving. That's what is used for birds.
"We don't see the numbers, but the kilograms of birds in the skies. What we did see recently is the amount of migration that has changed. It's a nice complement to what's seen on ground. Radar gives really good coverage. With radar, we can count many more birds than what we could count on the ground."
Bird biomass in the skies has decreased by about 14% since 2007, Dokter told the Cornell Chronicle, Cornell University's in-house publication.
"The decline in night skies might be steeper than what we see on the ground. It's migratory birds, especially birds that travel long distance ... they seem to be not doing too well," Dokter said. "It's what I want to document next, and the why and what we can do to turn it around. Where do they face the most problems and challenges?"
Outside of weather radar data, scientists looked through more than 500 surveys, Rosenberg said. They then used a statistical model to analyze the data.
Locals get involved in tracking bird population The primary data source was the North American Breeding Bird Survey, which started in 1966 as a collaboration between scientists and bird-watchers.
While there have been studies on the changes of bird populations on the continent, the most recent study was the first time anyone has ever collected and analyzed 50 years' worth of data and findings in North America.
For decades, countless passionate non-professional bird-watchers have submitted their observations to databases. In the new research, professionals examined those studies to estimate the populations of 529 species from 2006 to 2015.
"The study published in Science was shocking to me, with its report of just how deeply bird populations have crashed since 1970," said Diane Morton, president of the Cayuga Bird Club. "The paper let us know that it is not just our subjective impression that there are fewer birds now, but that hundreds of different bird species really are much, much less abundant than they used to be.
"Among other alarming declines, the authors reported that forest birds like warblers, and grassland species like meadowlarks and sparrows, now number hundreds of millions fewer than in the 1970s."
The Cayuga Bird Club's annual Christmas Bird Count contributed to the findings. In addition, the club also counts birds for the New York State Breeding Bird Atlas.
"It was rewarding for those of us who participate in the annual Christmas Bird Count to know that the numbers we gather in our bird counts year after year were useful for these analyses," Morton said. "We did not provide any direct input, but our participation in citizen science projects generated some of the data that this extensive study used."
Surveys by Rosenberg and other local scientists contributed as well.
"The birders are the eyes of the world," he said. "You need to have all the eyes and ears out there because scientists can't do it alone. But it's not just the observation of amateurs. It's data collected for the purpose of the survey."
Birds that have seen the largest decrease The research shows most of the birds lost belong to 12 families, including warblers, finches, sparrows and swallows.
Birds associated with farmlands have seen the largest decline in numbers and percentage.
"Some birds in our backyards are the steepest in decline that we see," Dokter said. "Hopefully, it will lead to action take care of nature."
Out of all of the bird families, the largest decline was among larks.
There are 70 million fewer Eastern meadowlarks, 60 million fewer Western meadowlarks, and a 67% decline for all larks.
"We're seeing this loss of abundance, because birds are integral parts of ecosystems. They perform ecological functions like seed dispersal," Rosenberg said.
"The loss of this chunk of birds is causing ecological consequences. Because we have this data on birds, the fear that is happening with birds is happening across the board with other animals."
What's being done for North American birds The National Audubon Society has responded strongly to the report and is mobilizing its 1.65 million members to urge lawmakers to act on bird conservation.
The organization is pushing for the passing of the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative Act and implementation of the Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan. Both plans focus on providing an optimal environment and water for birds in the regions.
The group also wants lawmakers to defend and reinforce the Migratory Bird Treaty Act, which the Trump administration has been trying to weaken. Conservationists say the Migratory Bird Treaty Act protects close to 1,000 species of North American birds and is the most import bird conservation law in the U.S.
What's next for the bird population The Cayuga Bird Club will census birds for the next New York Breeding Bird Atlas, which will have five years of surveys starting from January 2020.
"The Science paper is a call to action," Morton said. "It has sparked more urgent discussion about how to address the decline of bird populations — through conservation management, changing the developed landscape to provide better habitat for birds, and taking individual steps to reduce the threats that birds face. Continued monitoring of bird populations will also be important for prioritizing conservation efforts."
Because the study did not state the reasons for the decrease in bird populations, Rosenberg said he and the researchers are assembling a group of experts early next year to investigate the causes of the declines.
"The most important thing is that this doesn't become a news flash," Rosenberg said "We want people to pay attention and to track birds. People who love birds have to speak up. ... We won't reverse the declines unless people who love birds demand action."
Follow Matt Steecker on Twitter @OnTheStecord.
"It was a shock at first, but maybe we should not have been surprised."
Ken Rosenberg
Applied conservation scientist, Cornell University
"The U.S. has a very large network of radars that cover ... anything in the sky — not just weather, but also wildlife. Birds give strong signals. More and more have realized this, and it's an important data source for biologists. If you look at it on your iPhone, you don't see the individual bird, but a blob of bio-life moving. That's what is used for birds."
Adriaan Dokter, a research associate at Cornell
How you can
help the birds
Individuals can take a variety of actions to help, including making windows safer, reducing plastic use, keeping cats indoors, using native plants and avoiding the use of pesticides. To learn more, visit 3billionbirds.org/.
Cayuga Bird Club members, from left, Jody Enck, Ken Kemphues, Bob McGuire, Ann Mitchell and Wes Blauvelt set up for winter birding in 2018.
Diane Morton/ Provided photo

Concern over more horse deaths looms at Breeders' Cup this weekend

Autor: Josh, Peter. 

Información de publicación: USA Today (Online) ; Arlington [Arlington]. 31 Oct 2019.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/concern-over-more-horse-deaths-looms-at-breeders/docview/2310737898/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Thirty-six horses have died at Santa Anita since December, and yet the venerable track will be the site of the Breeders' Cup this weekend.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Concern+over+more+horse+deaths+looms+at+Breeders%27+Cup+this+weekend&amp;author=Josh%2C+Peter&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2019-10-31&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=USA+Today+%28Online%29&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anorthcentralnews_

Texto completo: ARCADIA, Calif. — Craig Fravel sat down in front of the grandstands at Santa Anita Park as he looked across the famed racetrack and into the distance.
“Sitting here at the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains, you can see why this is such a great venue for the Breeders’ Cup,’’ Fravel, CEO and president of the Breeders’ Cup, told USA TODAY Sports this week. “It’s a spectacularly beautiful place. ”
Yet it’s also fraught with tension and scrutiny as the annual two-day horse racing event is set to begin Friday.
The 36th running of the Breeders’ Cup, 14 races with purses of no less than $1 million each that culminate with the $6 million Breeders' Cup Classic,has attracted many of the sport’s top horses. It's also certain to attract protesters decrying a string of horse deaths at Santa Anita — 36 deaths since December.
The deaths have activated animal rights groups such as PETA and led to an investigation by the Los Angeles District Attorney’s office.
Yet in June, with a chance to move the Breeders’ Cup to famed Churchill Downs in Louisville, Kentucky or another racetrack, the organization’s board of directors voted to keep the event at Santa Anita, which will be hosting the Breeders’ Cup for a record 10th time.
Fravel has dismissed the idea that his accepting a new job with the Stronach Group, which owns Santa Anita Park, influenced the Breeders’ Cup board’s decision to keep the event here.
'IT'S JUST A JOB TO ME': Horses go from racetracks to slaughterhouses
INVESTIGATION: Horse racing deaths mount as states spend billions to keep tracks alive
“It wasn’t really that hard a decision because it was the right thing to do and we needed to acknowledge people were taking the right kind of steps that we believe are important for the whole industry to take,’’ said Fravel, who after the Breeders' Cup will become CEO of racing operations for the Stronach Group, which owns six other thoroughbred racing tracks.
Unable to slow the alarming rate of horse deaths, Santa Anita shut down racing for almost all of March. Two experts were brought in to inspect the track. The Stronach Group later announced the track was deemed fit to resume racing.
Reform followed.
The use of race-day medication was banned with the exception of Lasix, and the Stronach Group has committed to phasing out permitted use of the potent diuretic. Jockeys faced new restrictions on the use of whips.
Dionne Benson, chief veterinary officer for the Stronach Group, said Santa Anita has reduced horse fatalities by almost 80% at its training track and by more than 50% on the racing track since the track reopened in late March. She cited Santa Anita increasing oversight and control as factors.
"From my perspective, that isn't the finish line,'' she said, referring to the reduced rate of deaths. "Our finish line is zero (deaths). That is our goal. We may never reach it.
"But every time we have an incident, every time we have any kind of injury to a horse, we need to figure out if there's a way it could have been prevented. ''
Toward that end, Benson said, the Stronach Group is investing in new medical technology for horses and will continue to work on regulatory, technology and education issues as "three ways to address any injury that we have with horses. ''
Despite racing reforms at Santa Anita and throughout the state, Gov. Gavin Newsom in September put California horse racing on notice during an interview with the New York Times.
“I’ll tell you, talk about a sport whose time is up unless they reform,’’ Newsom told the Times. “That’s horse racing. Incredible abuses to these precious animals and the willingness to just to spit these animals out and literally take their lives is a disgrace. ”
In addition to the horse deaths, Newsom pointed to another troubling matter: In September, the New York Times reported that Justify, winner of the 2018 Triple Crown, failed a drug test after winning the Santa Anita Derby — a victory that preceded the horse’s sweeping the Kentucky Derby, Preakness Stakes and Belmont Stakes. Yet California horse racing regulators disposed of the inquiry behind closed doors, the New York Times reported.
Earlier this week, Jim Gagliano, president and chief operating officer of the Jockey Club, said the sport of horse racing is facing a reckoning.
“Safety and integrity, those are fundamental matters for any sporting competition,’’ said Gagliano, who is helping spearhead a push for federal legislation — the Horse Racing Integrity Act — that would establish a central body responsible for drug testing horses. “This is a gambling sport. Integrity has to be of the highest variety. ’’
But reality has cast a shadow over talk of reforms. During buildup to the 2019 Breeders’ Cup, the horse death toll at Santa Anita continued to mount.
On Oct. 25, G Q Covergirl, a six-year-old mare, was euthanized after injuring her front legs while on the training track. On Sunday, Bye Bye Beautiful, a 2-year-old filly, was euthanized after she injured her front right leg during a race.
“Like I've been arguing for a long time, they can't stop the killing,’’ Patrick Battuello, an animal rights activist focused on the death of racehorses, said. "It's built in to the system. "
Yet Fravel, wearing a purple Breeders’ Cup sweatshirt as he sat in front of the Santa Anita grandstands earlier this week, looked serene with the view of the San Gabriel Mountains in the distance.
“I take comfort in the fact that we’ve done everything that we can to control the controllable,’’ Fravel said. “What misfortune could occur that we can’t avoid, I worry about it but that’s just because I’m a worrier, not because we haven’t done everything we can do to address it. ’’
This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Concern over more horse deaths looms at Breeders' Cup this weekend

Simsbury could add women to council

Autor: Brindley, Emily. 

Información de publicación: Hartford Courant ; Hartford, Conn. [Hartford, Conn]. 31 Oct 2019: B.3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/simsbury-could-add-women-council/docview/2310566307/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Simsbury+could+add+women+to+council&amp;author=Brindley%2C+Emily&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.3&amp;date=2019-10-31&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Hartford+Courant&amp;issn=1047-4153&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: SIMSBURY - Currently, Simsbury's five-member Board of Selectmen includes only one woman. But next week, that could change.
For the Nov. 5 municipal elections, the local Republicans have put forward a slate that, including down-ballot candidates, has more women than men.
This includes Cheryl Cook, who is currently the sole female member of the Board of Selectmen. In next week's election, Cook will vie for the top elected seat in town: first selectman.
Cook said that no one, including herself, at first noticed that she was the only successful female candidate in the 2017 election, when she won her second two-year term on the Board of Selectmen.
"People really didn't realize it had happened until it did," Cook said. "It really wasn't even on the radar."
Cook hopes to see more women running for office, which would give the elected boards another perspective to consider.
Both the Democrats and the Republicans have nominated a slate of candidates for the town's boards, including the education board, finance board, the planning commission and others.
The Board of Selectmen, however, is the highest board in the town.
The Democratic candidates for the Board of Selectmen are:
*Incumbent Eric Wellman for first selectman
* Incumbent Chris Peterson
* Newcomer Philip Purciello, who previously ran as a Republican
* Newcomer Wendy Mackstutis
The Republican candidates for Board of Selectmen are:
* Cheryl Cook for first selectman
* Newcomer Jackie Battos
* Incumbent Sean Askham
* Incumbent Mike Paine
In addition, petitioning candidate Robert Kalechman is also running for first selectman.
Cook and Battos, the two Republican women running for the Board of Selectmen, said that the current board does its job well.
More women on the board would give the board more viewpoints to draw from, they both said.
"The Board of Selectmen is fantastic, they do a great job," Battos said. "It's (about) another voice and having another voice."
Despite the composition of the town's highest elected board, the town of Simsbury is run by only men.
On the career side of the coin, the town has three high-ranking female executives in town manager Maria Capriola, deputy town manager Melissa Appleby and finance director Amy Meriwether.
Cook and Battos said local woman are also already involved in town happenings, particularly in volunteer positions that keep the town operating smoothly.
"There are women who have been involved in town for a long time," Cook said. But "it takes some courage to put your name on the ballot and I understand that."
As The New York Times reported in 2018, female politicians are subjected to all kinds of verbal abuse, sometimes including credible threats of violence.
At a 2018 meeting organized by UN Women, one expert presented a study showing, of women in parliaments across 39 countries, nearly 82 percent "experienced psychological violence."
Although those issues are often tamer in municipal elections, the problem still exists.
Cook, who has already sat on the Board of Selectmen for about six years, said that the vitriol directed at her has intensified now that's running for first selectman. That's especially true online, she said.
"People feel a lot freer to say things online that they would probably never say to your face," Cook said. "You don't want to put an emotional face on it but sometimes it does hurt."
Mackstutis, the Democratic woman running for the Board of Selectmen, said she's been targeted by some "trolls" online since announcing her candidacy.
Mackstutis said the trolls have directed about the same amount of anger at her as they direct at First Selectman Wellman - but Wellman is already sitting in an elected position, a step above the position that Mackstutis is seeking.
"Social media does impact you at the local level, which was a surprise to me," Mackstutis said.
For the highest position in town, first selectman, there's a three-way race.
Wellman - the Democrat who's currently in his first term as first selectman, after winning an underdog race in 2017 - said that he would focus a second term on continuing the economic development, extending the East Coast Greenway and making the town more efficient.
He also noted that Simsbury is still in a state of transition, after moving to the town manager style of government about two years ago.
"This is a journey we're on. We've had more change in two years in our local government than in probably any other two-year period in anyone's memory," Wellman said.
Cook, the Republican candidate for first selectman, said she sees herself as a policy maker.
If elected first selectman, Cook said, she would focus on supporting initiatives that assist people who are in recovery from addiction. She would also look to expand local transportation options, which she said is especially important as the town's population ages.
"There's a lot of things swirling around, but I am really committed to doing this as a full-time job if I'm elected," Cook said.
Kalechman, the petitioning candidate for first selectmen, said his first priority would be to address high taxes affecting Simsbury residents. He also said he's opposed to the Curaleaf production facility on Hopmeadow Street. Curaleaf is one of a handful of licensed cannabis growers in the state.
"We have no leadership in town. The people do not have a voice," Kalechman said.
Emily Brindley can be reached at ebrindley@courant.com.

Pedestrians in the crosshairs

Información de publicación: Valley News ; White River Junction, Vt. [White River Junction, Vt]. 31 Oct 2019: 1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/pedestrians-crosshairs/docview/2310552059/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Pedestrians+in+the+crosshairs&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=1&amp;date=2019-10-31&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Valley+News&amp;issn=1072-6179&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: The dark season is upon us again, and the terrors it holds are hardly confined to Halloween. Low visibility combined with the inclement weather that is surely just around the calendar corner in our part of the world pose increased traffic safety risks.
This reflection is prompted by statistics reported last week by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: More pedestrians and bicyclists were killed in 2018 than in any year since 1990, even as total traffic deaths decreased. The NHTSA said that 6,283 pedestrians were killed last year, an increase of 3.4% from 2017, while 857 bicyclists died, an increase of 6.3%. Combined, those two categories accounted for about 20% of all traffic deaths.
The agency also noted that the overall traffic safety picture has been improving for the past 40 years, as manufacturers have added features such as air bags and electronic stability control, and public awareness campaigns have led to increased seat belt use and decreased impaired driving.
So why are “outside of vehicle” fatalities spiking?
Experts interviewed by The New York Times pointed to the driving public’s taste for larger SUVs and trucks, which are more prone to running over pedestrians rather than throwing them up over the hood. This, combined with the heavier impact imparted during a collision and larger blind spots, may be contributing to more such deaths, they surmised.
This is not to mention the dangers inherent in distracted driving. About 3.2% of drivers on the road on a given day are using cellphones, according to the Times. (We also wonder about distracted walking, having seen on more than a couple of occasions in Hanover pedestrians who were blissfully unaware that they were straying out into traffic while using their phones.)
And, now, about that darkness, which poses special challenges to aging eyes, of which there are many in Vermont and New Hampshire. (The percentage of drivers 65 and older involved in fatal crashes has increased nearly 35% over 10 years.)
Nighttime fatalities involving pedestrians rose 4.6% from 2017 to 2018, while those involving bicyclists went up 9.2%. This may be an unfortunate side effect of an otherwise positive development: More people are walking and biking for health and environmental reasons, a trend certainly noticeable in the Upper Valley.
Something else that is quite evident to us is that reckless driving is spiking rapidly here. For instance, the morning commute on Interstate 89 often resembles nothing so much as the Wild West, combining high speed, immense pickup trucks and SUVs, unsignaled lane changes and a general aggression previously associated primarily with neighboring states to the south. If that kind of driving spills over to roads frequented by pedestrians and bicyclists, it constitutes a distinct menace to them.
So, drivers, on Halloween night, when children are more likely to be walking about than usual, be extra careful. And, then, resolve to drive in like fashion every subsequent night, and day, sharing the road safely with walkers and bicyclists. If you need a refresher on how to do that, the NHTSA website — https://www.nhtsa.gov/road-safety/pedestrian-safety — has useful safety tips for both drivers and pedestrians, who also need to know how best to protect themselves from injury or death.

An Exemplar of 'Truth, Honor and Duty'

Información de publicación: New York Times , Late Edition (East Coast); New York, N.Y. [New York, N.Y]. 31 Oct 2019: A.28.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/exemplar-truth-honor-duty/docview/2310543483/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=unknown&amp;atitle=An+Exemplar+of+%27Truth%2C+Honor+and+Duty%27%3A+%5BLetter%5D&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.28&amp;date=2019-10-31&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;issn=0362-4331&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anytimes_

Texto completo: Readers praise the colonel who gave testimony before Congress as a patriot and hero.
To the Editor:
Re "Colonel Tried to Fill Gaps in Ukraine Call Transcript" (front page, Oct. 30):
I read Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman's opening statement before the House Committees on Intelligence, Foreign Affairs and Oversight. Can there be a more overwhelmingly compelling statement of what happened between Ukrainian and American officials?
Colonel Vindman came to this country at age 3 from Ukraine. He wanted nothing more than to serve the United States, and he has in myriad ways. He states that he is -- and certainly sounds -- utterly nonpartisan.
During a July 10 meeting with Oleksandr Danylyuk, a senior government official from Ukraine, Gordon Sondland, ambassador to the European Union, talked about the need to deliver "specific investigations" in order to secure a meeting with President Trump.
After that meeting, according to Colonel Vindman's testimony, "I stated to Amb. Sondland that his statements were inappropriate, that the request to investigate Biden and his son had nothing to do with national security, and that such investigations were not something the N.S.C. was going to get involved in or push."
Colonel Vindman's testimony is devastating. Can anyone find otherwise?
Marc Chafetz
Washington
To the Editor:
If a young person wonders whether his government can be trusted, if a dispirited citizen is unsure her country is worth loving, if an immigrant asks what America stands for, they have only to look at the photograph of Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman going to testify in the Capitol to know the answer.
Here is the epitome of public service, a person who knows what truth, honor and duty mean and why they matter. This is what patriotism looks like, what courage consists of, what a hero is. Colonel Vindman continues his work of defending and protecting our nation. His example gives the inspiration we need. His action renews our faith that one person can make a difference, that sunlight will break the darkness. Thank you, sir.
Jonathan Gibson
Shrewsbury, Vt.
To the Editor:
Re "On Far Right, Pundits Stoke Conspiracies on Witness" (news article, Oct. 30):
Look at all the medals and ribbons on the uniform of Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, a Purple Heart recipient, and then consider how vile and desperate Fox News and right-wing commentators are to stoop so low as to challenge this hero's loyalty to the United States. Have you folks no decency?
Arthur Salz
Kew Gardens, Queens
Photograph Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman met with House impeachment investigators on Tuesday. (PHOTOGRAPH BY Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)
